Some vaults should be kept an eye on, because sometimes the sleeping dead are not the only things down there.
No subsurface rat-creatures will gnaw on these bones – not while the Vault Guard has anything to say about it!
Elite skeletal sentries patrol the large tombs of the undying, ensuring only the children of Nehekhara roam their halls.
“If them ratmen are around, we'll find 'em, just make sure the Zombie Deckhands keepin' watch actually 'ave eyes…”
A good lookout keeps their eyes moving, watching for the smallest hint of enemy activity.
Where the light shines, a keen eye follows, surveying the area for signs of the Skaven menace.
The Dark Ones’ malice and hate should not cloud their judgement when it comes to staying prepared against Skaven-caused inconveniences.
The Druchii guards take no prisoners once the foul vermin's presence is sniffed out.
Numerous barricades block these subterranean tunnels, halting the progress of any loathsome Skaven assailants.
With their shadows flickering from the incandescent light of enchanted torches, the citizen-watchmen make their rounds.
A trained force of Watchmen scour the tunnels beneath the city, staying alert to any sign of the filthy creatures that might call these hollows home.
Asur guards patrol the blockade, surveying the tunnels as far as the eye can see, while expert scouts journey out into the dark.
Some Lizardmen tunnels date back to an earlier age, predating all the younger races and so are totally unknown to them.
The Cold Ones study ancient maps of long lost underground passages, providing an advantageous familiarity with the subterranean landscape.
A complex maze of ancient underground tunnels has been rebuilt, a key network for scouts and spies.
The Skaven know their rivals would happily burrow out spy-dens beneath them, the only defence being to spy straight down themselves.
The deeper the burrow, the greater the advantage', or so the saying goes.
Rival clans will think twice before attempting to sneak past a nest of elite subterranean spies.
Those vermin will be eradicated, wherever they seek to hide!
A central camp equips Chaos Scouts with everything they need to catch and kill any Ratkin seeking to interfere with the Dark Gods' plans.
A dedicated force of Skaven hunters venture forth, ready to crush skulls the second any of the rodents rear their ugly heads.
To protect the forest’s roots from the Skaven threat, guardianship can be provided over its lowest lying levels.
Deep crevices in the earth provide a line of sight underground, illuminating those that had hoped to lurk in the dark.
The roots of the forest sink deep into the soil, winding through caves used by scouts, spies, and lookouts.
Having faced far more abominable beasts than the Skaven, the Northmen relish "pest control duties".
The verminous Skaven leave a clear enough trail; follow the stink and you'll find them.
Fortified outposts dot the landscape, where the men of the north watch eagerly for their chance to cut a bloody swathe through the verminous tides.
When peasants start vanishing, it may be necessary to start a night watch lest the lords and nobles be next.
Any vermin attempting to sneak past the Watch House will meet the sharp end of a Watchman's blade.
Only the sharpest eyes belong to the Guild, honour bound to uncover hidden threats wherever they conceal themselves.
The Dwarfs’ ancient underground highways depend on the vigilance of lookouts to keep the Dwarfholds prepared for Skaven aggression.
Well-equipped lookout stations have been erected underground, alerting the Dawi when the ratmen advance.
Multiple sets of eyes are better than one, when it comes to seeking out an infestation of vermin.
Only the most foolhardy nations of men ignore the cautionary tale that is "The Doom of Kavzar".
Mere scouts are not enough; when the Skaven menace descends, well-equipped Watchers must be ready to call their brothers to arms.
Hunters, trackers and warriors of the highest calibre all do their part to patrol the underground in search of foul ratkin.
The employment of Night Goblins, who know how to avoid being tricked into the Skaven’s backstabbing plots, ensures the underground is watched.
Night Goblin trackers venture further afield, scouting the underground for any sign of Skaven activity.
The Skaven may be tricksy foes, but the Trapperz have a few tricks of their own up their sleeves.
Some vaults should be kept an eye on, because sometimes the sleeping dead are not the only things down there.
Eagle-eyed sentries stalk the catacombs of the Undead, keeping a watchful eye out for any underground intruders with a pulse.
A force of the finest scouts roam the dark, tracking the sickening scent of vermin below the earth.
The Liche King proselytises his master, Nagash; his Black Tower juts skyward, a declaration of his dark and cruel intent.
Alcadizaar's pyramid stands as eternal proof of his sacrifice to prevent Nagash's nefarious plans reaching fruition.
The King of the Fleetport is forever immortalised by his colossal pyramid.
The Liche Lord commanded his great pyramid constructed, so that in life and beyond, all will know his resilience and dedication.
This monument, much like the man himself, is defiant against the otherwise unstoppable march of Settra's armies.
The pyramid of the Imperishable commands the respect and dread of all who gaze upon it.
The Eternal Prince promises bounty and prosperity to his lands, in exchange for glorious exultation, naturally.
A tumulus of corpses from a long-faded civilisation, now occupied by new denizens.
Spirits of long-dead warriors linger in the mound, eager to take to the battlefield once again.
Many a rider has lost their steed in the treacherous drifting sands. The corpses still litter the fast-holding mires.
Countless soldiers have fallen in battle. In the wake of Nagash, they will all rise to fight again.
Next to every great temple of the Mortuary Cult lies a covered pit in which its deadly, ophic guardians dwell.
Great beasts of burden and horrors of the desert, broken and made to serve their Undead masters.
The crack of cartilage, the snap, the whine, and the howls of delight define the Bonemaster's work.
The gleaming carriages of the Nehekharan chariots shine with the power of the brassworker's mastery.
What better ammunition for catapults than the flaming, screaming skulls of the defeated dead?
The Tomb Kings' citadels dominate the landscape of the desert, fixed and imposing amongst the ever-shifting sands.
Interred in resplendent and decadent tombs, Nehekharan royalty lie in repose until their kingdom calls them hence.
The lookouts are dark blotches on a horizon of sand; vigilant hawks against the horrors of the desert.
A column of gleaming bone holds a stern and ominous watch over the shifting and treacherous Nehekharan sands.
From the death houses of Nehekhara, the dead continue to rise to fulfil their as-yet unfinished duty.
Those of noble blood are interred in the royal catacombs, awakening to pursue their living aspirations once more.
Glittering chambers of worked and preserved bone provide the perfect sanctuary for the resting dead.
Gaze upon the face of Tomb Kings past - the Hierotitan is the likeness of Nehekhara's sovereigns made massive.
In the once-resplendent streets of the Nehekharan cities, the dead shuffle about their business as if nothing has changed.
Death is more than a business now, it is life itself!
Great edifices flank the streets of the great Nehekharan cities; monuments to those who came before.
Those consigned to another world, revived to an insipid parody of life to do their master's bidding.
Interred at their liege lord's request, these soldiers are ready to fight again at a moment's notice.
The Tomb Kings demanded loyalty from their soldiers until death and beyond. In Unlife, they expect the same.
The abominable Necrosphinx towers above the Nehekharans, offering protection and destruction in exchange for hushed and cowed adoration.
The punishing desert cannot confine the Tomb Kings; the oceans call and Nehekhara answers!
Pushing off from deathly still waters, the Tomb Kings take their unearthly conquest across the placid deep.
The Nehekharan armada slips across stagnant oceans, delivering fury and domination to the living world beyond.
Obelisks tower over the horizon, casting judgement upon any caught in their shadow.
The dead all need a place to rest; until they rise again, of course.
For the Tomb Kings, there is only eternal Unlife - their sanctuaries are thus a testament to decrepitude.
Even the animals and beasts of Nehekhara could not escape Nagash's terrible curse, nor their masters' ever-living adoration.
The deep red mineral glows with a supernatural presence and is much vaunted by the Nehekharan rulers.
The tanneries of Nehekhara churn even in Undeath; the stench of acid and death pervades the desolate streets.
An empire as proud and vain as the Tomb Kings' requires magnificent stones to be unearthed in ever-increasing amounts.
All that glitters may not be gold, but there are certainly copious quantities of it adorning Nehekhara's rulers.
New iron is required for swords, for shields, for war; not all of Nehekhara is left to rot.
The great statues of Khemri can only be built from marble drawn by bone-breaking labour in the quarry.
Smoke and noise billow and bellow from within, as dark and curious transmutations are perfected.
The dark stones of the Obsidian mines glint with a deathly, otherworldly gleam.
Even in the vast desert, there are beacons of hope that give way to phantasms of decay.
The trappings of life, endlessly recreated in death.
In the desert, decay sets in fast. Preservation is key, for food and flesh alike.
Even for desert dwellers, the spice merchants are insalubrious. Yet the precious spice, they continually insist, *must* flow.
Despite everything, the skeletal populace of Nehekhara do so enjoy a good vintage…
More lumber must be sourced to prop up the crumbling edifices of ancient empires…
It is not the sting of the Scorpion that kills, but rather its powerful claws and voracious, insatiable appetite.
The dead return, unaware that what was once their grave is now also their home.
Mastaba or ‘houses of eternity’ are, typically, flat-roofed tombs. Like all crypts in Nehekhara, once built, settlements soon rose up around them.
These expansive, decadent testaments to death now teem with clamorous, violent Unlife.
The dark visions of Unlife that emerge from these tombs will, when done, return.
Great monuments to the departed, twisted into far-reaching cities of the dead.

Great monuments to the departed, twisted into far-reaching cities of the dead.
The City of Kings is an eternal monument to the sovereigns of the desert.
May the God of the Skies bless the warriors that stride forth in his name.
Deep inside the Pyramid of Nagash is said to be a vault, cursed with Undead magic by the fabled Necromancer himself. Only very few know what secrets it truly holds.
The heat-bleached bone warriors of grim countenance watch over the battlements, watching for foes through hollowed sockets.
These lithified walls have seen empires rise and fall, and endured the accession of doom. They hold.
The hieroglyphics inscribed upon these battlements channel protective wards, fending off any would-be invaders.
The might of the Khemrian Warsphinx stands astride the cities of the dead, roaring eternally.
The secret meeting place of the Aesanar, the sons and heirs of the Shadow King.
From high in the lush forest canopy the Handmaidens observe Alarielle's court, awaiting her summons.
When Alith Anar and his warriors strike, no quarter is shown to hated traitor-kin; their bodies used as examples, and tools of terror.
A palace of murder and hatred, now part of the High Elf realm, let the power of the Cadai inhabit its tortured structure.
This ancient portal connects the benighted forest-ways of the world that currently lie dormant.
An ancient portal connecting the forest-ways of the world. Young shoots show growth along its withered state.
An ancient portal connecting the forest-ways of the world, fully revived and tapping directly into the root networks of old.
Your local pirate tavern: good food, the best rum and quite a lot of murder - fun for all the family!
It's not actually hidden, it's just that most are just too afraid to go there.
A pleasant place to rest at the end of a long day of plundering the high seas with your mates.
Where there is demand for something, you can bet there'll be someone willing to risk all to bring it ashore.
To repair his fragmented psyche there are no depths to which Harkon will not sink.
Luthor Harkon's mind is broken and he believes the key to his condition lies buried... somewhere…
When the curtain rises, all assembled will fall prostrate afore the 'Siren of the Storm'.
Fashioned from the tooth of a mighty Dragon, the lighthouse affords its owner a much better view of exactly what is out there.
The wreck of the Grand Theogonist's flagship has large bulkheads and hundreds of cannons that could be salvaged for a much greater purpose.
The sentient whirlpool at the centre of the Galleon's Graveyard pulls great sea-going vessels into its gaping maw, wherein Noctilus bides his time and awaits his chance.

Very nasty - tends to rip ‘em apart and send ‘em down to Stromfels’ Chest with all hands lost… to my true father's delight!
…from which the great soprano - the Siren of the Sea, no less - connects with 'her public'.
Within this ornate sarcophagus of blackened oak, Harkon plots his return. Perhaps a name for an even greater vessel to come?
Darts are for firing as well as throwing - with deadly results.
A hook next to the tip ensures that a dart is rather difficult to remove, and struggling just makes its gashed wound worse.
This barbed spear is ideal for hunting big fish, men, Orcs, Ogres - whatever!
Three prongs are definitely better than one.
The addition of a rope stops the quarry from simply limping away to fight another day.
It aids defence greatly when attackers can be turned to fight for them.
Here, in this terrible place, the ship transporting Luthor Harkon's coffin ran aground, cursing the region for evermore with the taint of Vampiric corruption and unleashing all the horrors of Unlife.
This desolate, unholy stretch of coastline is where Harkon's ship ran aground, and where his freshly-recruited pirate crew set up his base of operations.
The roaring sea-winds and deadly, twisting currents protect Harkon's base from unwanted attention whilst simultaneously trapping unwary seafarers.
Here the place now known as the Vampire Coast lies, infamous home to a dread pirate fleet crewed exclusively by the dead and damned.
The greatest power in the Undead world resides here, in his clifftop stronghold, when not sailing the high seas in search of plunder, glory, and the key to restoring his fractured mind.
A legendary settlement lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Slow on the uptake they might be, but zombies make effective guards once they smell living flesh approaching.
To the casual observer, there is no garrison…
A simple enclosure of stakes forms an adequate defence against the living, and an even better one against those who have tasted the Blood Kiss…
Obstacles like this slow the enemy's progress. The more broken, the better.
Features such as these provide a useful protective screen behind which archers and gunners can reload.
One man's personal totem can be the banner for an entire race.
Gaze upon Undeath's true face and despair, mortals, for all hope be lost to you.
The dead and the damned, eternally burning, as is their lot.
Nature provides all that's required to dispatch the living from this world and into our service.
Hangman, hangman, hold it a little while…
I wanna see 'em swingin' from the yard arm, yarrrrrr!!!
Once-proud warriors reduced to pitiful, mewling minions who'd gladly kill each other for an extra scrap of bread.
Roll up, roll up - come 'n' get yer fresh mea… I mean able-bodied labour force!
From humble beginnings, enormous stashes may grow.
The sensible pirate brings a bag along as insurance, for when insensible later on he may forget where he left his plunder.
If you're careful, and observe the correct litanies, a good haul of treasure will last quite some time.
Lads, we're gonna need a bigger boat…
'X' marks the spot.
Keep them fed or they're likely to break free and eat you!
Somewhere safe to play card or dice after hours… and after lives.
All together now... 'Yo ho, blow the man down!'
Keeping all your potential recruits in one place makes mustering a far more straightforward process.
Finding the right kind of crew - not too green but still hungry for war and lucre - doesn't have to be a difficult matter.
Here some of the greatest right-hand men in history are laid to rest… temporarily at least.
A fine resting place for the most audacious naval commanders of all time, until the time comes for them to serve once more.
The experienced Necromancer knows all the nooks where the Fell Bats nest.
Here the winged monsters of the air settle and nest.
Stromfels' scaly backside! Duck! Now, quickly, get it with the tranquiliser harpoon!
There, my pretties, promised you a feast, didn't I?
There's a fair chance that some of them won't work and some will explode, but that's not so important as their owners are already dead.
If it goes bang and doesn't blow the shooter to pieces, who cares where it came from?
Be wary of the Undead bearing projectiles.
What's been destroyed can be recreated.
This useful inlet was carefully chosen for its geographical position - easy to locate at sea and impossible to spot from the coast.
For the bolder pirate who fears nothing, and especially not death, for none can die a second time.
From here, large quantities of plundered goods can be safely unloaded and transported inland for sale.
This once-bustling port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Every legendary enterprise has to start somewhere.
It may look like a motley collection of huts and boxes, but here, seeds of greatness flourish.
When they come for you, be ready.
Far more than just a simple hideout, this place has genuine pirating potential.
A highly-defensible location; tricky to assault and with plenty of room, it's the ideal place for pirates to rest up between actions.
A legendary settlement lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
This hive of villainy houses the Undead crews in between sea-borne raids.
A filthy, broken-down place, where evil plans are hatched and dark plots germinate.
Somewhere to lie low, to count loot and plot fresh schemes.
Successful pirates get to enjoy some of their pickings; a lair is also a place in which to hole-up and live the good life for a while.
Get hold of enough filthy lucre and things get complicated - much effort must be expended defending it from friends and enemies alike.
This shoreline is littered with putrid bivouacs, under which the pirates shelter in between voyages.
These wretched makeshift dwellings house dead men and dark forces.
A place of relative safety, where stolen booty can be split, counted and stashed.
This harbour is large enough for larger pirate vessels to moor and unload.
Ships laden with seized treasure harbour here, their stashes well guarded in case of attack.
This city-port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
No one here lives, and can recall only fleeting memories of their lives before.
Inside these filthy spaces, even-filthier pirate scum plan future endeavours and plot dire revenge.
The filthy hovels and huts are numerous enough here for a pirate community of sorts to have developed.
Among these decrepit lean-tos and improvised shelters, the Undead crews pass the time between missions.
Only the Undead dwell here, among the trinkets and treasure they've taken as prizes.
Here, in this unholy place, dead men tell tales of high-seas plunder.
This port-town lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
This town lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Useful for keeping the ship moored, assuming it's a calm day anyway.
Such things are useful if you don't want to lose the lot - ship, crew and cargo!
Hand-forged in the Empire's industrial heartland, hand-stolen off the coast of Kislev.
Although little more than a horizontal mortar, the bombard still packs one hell of a punch.
These short, cast iron 'cannonettes' were made in the Imperial foundries at Nuln, guaranteeing their reliability, assuming they're always correctly maintained.
Hahaaaa! I’d like to see 'em come back after a broadside from these babies! Yarrrr!
When your boat's not that big, each space must have several different functions.
Here, decisions are made, booty is split, meals are ravenously consumed and tired freebooters rest their weary pegs.
At last! I've made it, Bernard - I've got me own room… Well, me own box anyway.
Adjacent to the bridge, the sea cabin contains basic amenities, so the cap'n is never too far from the action.
Rather fitting for a great pirate lord, don't you think?
I don't envy the poor swine 'oo as to balance up there!
Just a chair lashed to a mast, but to the crow it's a throne.
Safer from harm, but not too comfortable - you don't want lookouts kipping on the job, after all.
A more elaborate structure enabling multiple lookouts, so all directions can be watched for signs of trouble ahead or marks to be boarded and stripped.
Time and money didn't allow for much else. At least they’re above the waterline… for now.
Glass isn't really necessary in this climate... unless of course you get caught in a bug storm off the coast of Nehekhara! Portholes are for guns, then, more oft than not.
Designed and built for a specific purpose, allowing for some flexibility of firing angles and gun elevations.
Look, Bernie - now we're just like the Imperial fleet! We’re gonna show 'em 'oos boss - you mark my words!
A basic arrangement that enables crude steering, but isn't ideal if you want to make swift manoeuvres.
A simple pole and ring system allows the helmsman to control the tiller from the deck.
A wheel is best - you can almost turn your boat on the head of a pin and cut them off before they can run.
If you're good, you'll run out of pockets very quickly.
This space is big enough to store plenty of stolen goods and new-found long-lost treasure.
For the really big hauls - the live ones you can't really keep anywhere else.
Rub a dub dub, two 'undred men in a tub…
The addition of a keel adds a great deal of stability to a ship's structure.
The bigger the ship, the more bulkheads, stringers, webs, girders and frames can be fitted, meaning more room for crew and loot.
Rigged together from spare poles, but a useful, if temporary, platform on which to work.
This is the highest deck of a sailing ship, stretching from bow to stern, from which it is commanded.
There's nothin' like the wind blowin' through yer skull to cool yer head and focus yer mind, yarrrr!!!
The grime and guns may be below, but this is where the really crucial decisions are made, depending on who you ask, of course…
If the wind is favourable and light, flying the royal sail will tend to keep you on time.
All the bigger ships fly a skysail in light winds to maintain or gently increase speed.
Where is that moonlight trail that leads to your side? Just like the moonraker goes, in search of his dream of gold.
Best to keep the shot and powder separately from bitter crewmen too fond of rum.
The pirate ships' batteries are maintained and stored here, before being loaded aboard ahead of an action.
It's just good common sense to keep your powder somewhere else, preferably well away from your guns and the men.
Some fish are considerably less benevolent than others.
Amongst the coastal swamps, dark shapes shimmer and twist, waiting for the command to strike.
From the darkest depths, the hideous, pulsating masses rise…
Some Vampires prefer sorcery to bladecraft.
The spawning of larger Salamanders requires spacious, caverned pools more akin to their dank, natural habitats.
Taking much time and many scars, those Skinks who survive bonding with the untrainable Ripperdactyls end up with terrifyingly powerful sky mounts.
Those Bretonnian subjects who worship the vengeful Sea-God must do so in secret, as in some quarters even uttering his name can mean summary execution.
Where the twisted Warlock Engineers of the Skaven manufacture their own brand of unimaginable doom.
Blessed slithering beast of the pit, accept this offering in the name of the Serpent-God and his Prophet!
The observable secrets of the Dark Moon shall become clear.
Only the most reckless individual would dare attempt to somehow pull celestial objects out of the sky… cue Ikit Claw.
In this grubby, subterranean grotto, a secret project of Warpstone-powered mass destruction begins…
The power to bring down civilisations at the push of a button, contained in a laboriously assembled steel orb.
The intertwisted, seething mass of vermin grows, churning in anticipation of war.
When the frenzy of murderous hysteria reaches its crescendo, a chaotic rolling tide of death shall surge upwards!
Emerging from man-sized sinkholes, scurrying shadows ruthlessly silence anyone with forbidden knowledge of the Under-City’s existence.
From assigned posts, clandestine killers keep the surface-dwellers oblivious to the menace that skittishly plots beneath their feet.
Tunnels and warrens dug deeper into the bowels of the earth provide more concealment for nefarious scheming.
The Skaven can sustain themselves on most races’ foodstuffs, which they pilfer indiscriminately regardless of freshness.
Gnawed bones and scraps of cloth is all that remains of those caught in the path of a Skaven scavenge-raid.
Those above are now nothing more than hunted creatures in their own dwellings – no dark corner is safe.
A Warp-token stashed is a Warp-token earned.
The manufacture of Warp-tokens directly from diluted chunks of Warpstone-permeated rock is a highly profitable enterprise.
Even the bravest of opportunistic Skaven thieves prefers to avoid confrontation.
A bit of clandestine threatening and extortion of those above ground is an effective way to generate funds.
The Skaven are masters of manipulating the wealthy, controlling them with fear to keep them firmly in their pocket.
As the Skaven know, the safest way to scurry undetected between any two locations is always underground.
Converging tunnels means no longer just travelling from one place to another, but from one place to many.
Sprawling passageways connected to other strategically important locations give the ratmen frightening martial mobility.
The chaotic military logistics of the Skaven benefits greatly from tunnel links that extend out in all directions.
A place connected to all other neighbouring Under-Empire strongholds; all tunnels in the locality lead here.
The digging out of hidden burrows beneath unsuspecting settlements is the first step of the Skaven's infiltration tactics.
Perhaps lacking the charm of the usual digs, but these underground Skaven hovels are still a home away from home.
The lairs of the ratmen remain unseen by the other things, but just below the world the Skaven lurk, ready to invade.
Here the Warlords and Chieftains scheme and plan, mustering support from lesser rivals while dodging the inevitable assassination attempts.
A hub of subterranean military might symbolising the influence and power of those in control of the Under-City.
Skavenslaves toil here in total darkness, their expendable lives valued at a pittance compared to the valuable minerals they gather.
The burrowing out of crawlways and mineshafts provides access to more exposed rock, increasing chances of finding more mineral deposits.
Submerged in toxic green smoke, gas-masked Engineers preside over unventilated vat-filled warrens where Warpstone is optimised for best use.
Wherever larger mineral deposits are found, immense caverns are gnawed out of the earth to form yieldable underground strip-mines.
There's little chance of taming such creatures, so it's best to keep them in their own enclosure, well away from anything remotely edible.
This much larger space is dedicated to the Lizardmen's beasts of burden and some of the Old Ones' relics they carry to war.
The ideal space in which to house the elder, most-revered Stegadons, in turn ensuring their compliance when being handled.
This reptile-made cavern is just about large enough to house the nigh-uncontrollable Cold Ones and instruct their riders.
The extremely rare Horned Ones are kept here, mainly to protect less aggressive lizards from their relentless aggression.
Here the mighty Terradons are spawned and raised to achieve every last bit of their devastating potential.
This special, high-ceilinged reptile house is used for rearing large, flying lizards and training their riders in some of the more complex airborne combat tactics.
The wildest, most unpredictable among nature's natural hunters are broken and trained here.
The really big beasts, who may inadvertently – or advertently – crush smaller creatures or spew flaming bile everywhere, are, naturally, housed separately.
Only the most focused, disciplined and powerful Saurus can even attempt to control these vicious apex predators.
This pyramid of power currently lies dormant, waiting for its functions – and therefore its place within the Great Plan - to be restored.
This sacred pyramid of the Old Ones is now functional once again.
Destiny awaits the careful and reverent flyer who successfully interprets the instructions in the Old Ones' texts to the very letter.
A portal of Itzl enables the Lizardmen to teleport small units of Dinosaurs with the blessing of the God of Beasts.
This doorway into the aether allows the Lizardmen to convey Dinosaur forces to any desired location, observed by Itzl, God of Beasts, and with his favour.
This gateway to the Geomantic Web means the Lizardmen can transport larger groups of Dinosaurs, to key positions anywhere in the world, with Itzl's assent and approbation.
A portal such as this enables the transportation of small bands of infantry warriors, overseen by the Old One Quetzl the Protector.
This aethereal doorway allows the Lizardmen to convey their infantry forces, under the Old One Quetzl's ever-protective gaze, directly to where they are needed.
The myriad infinitesimal intricacies of the Geomantic Web allow the Lizardmen to teleport larger infantry forces, guided to safety by the Protector.
This portal allows small bands of mounted warriors to be teleported around the world, under the always-vigilant eye of Tlanxla the Warrior-God.
Aethereal gateways like this one give the Lizardmen the ability to transport their cavalry forces, observed by the Warrior-God's keen eyes and guided by His claw.
Using this Geomantic portal makes it possible for the Lizardmen to move large cavalry forces with the favour of the Warrior-God, Tlanxla.
Despite its run-down state, the mighty Saurus legions will once again spawn here.
Now its climate has been fixed and food supply secured, this Saurus spawning chamber is operational once more.
An expansive chamber built around a large, shallow spawning pool – the perfect conditions for raising the powerful, savage Saurus leaders.
The largest spawning chamber is reserved for the uncommon, honoured Temple Guard.
This is where the veteran Saurus are gathered, waiting to play their part in the Old Ones' master plan.
Figuring out the intricacies of the Great Plan, and how best to execute its instructions, requires serious and secluded contemplation.

Splendour and magnificence, to pay glory to Asuryan.

Drifting glades revolve in an eternal dance, where the Slann contemplate when the glades align in auspicious patterns.
Built more of instinctual reverence than true understanding of the Old Ones' geomantic alignment, Skink engineers still erect monolithic structures of inscrutable design.
Their religious ardour pointed squarely at the apexes of the pyramid-temples, few Lizardmen can fathom the power stowed away in vaulted devices and mummified Slann.
Pliodons are large, river-going creatures that seldom move on to land. They are used by the Lizardmen to ferry cohorts across bodies of water.
Natural harbours fashioned long ago by the Old Ones themselves, and now used by their servants.
Temple-cities close to the coast or major rivers will have designated port districts, where sea-going vessels of the Lizardmen make anchor.
The collecting of Itzl's creations, especially the colour changing chameleons, is deigned of use by the Slann.
Rarer Terradons distinguished by different beaks or patina are caged until tamed.
The great paddocks are where creatures are displayed and Skink Priests come with the blessings of Itzl and Conalxa.
Blood rock is a key ingredient in creating dyes for daubing on scales.
Blood rock mines are larger excavation sites, made when substantial cinnabar deposits are discovered.
Much blood rock is collected, ground with grit and thrown into sandstone vats, to create the dye.
Wearing the warmblood's skin is a good way to intimidate warmblood foes.
Skinks gemcutters are always in demand, as powerful crystals are used throughout the Lizardmen realms.
Gold holds a strange value to warmbloods, but for the Lizardmen it is a highly conductive and useful material.
Gold is melted down on thermal streams and then fashioned into any image the Mage-Priests desire.
Ore is taken from deep pits or mines; Kroxigor perform the labour but Skinks may have to work in smaller shafts.
Using methods described on plaque, the ore is heated and weapons can then be fashioned.
Marble is used in some form in certain temple-cities, but is not always the preferred material.
Skink adepts with a proficiency for stone carve images of the Old Ones into the walls of temple-cities.
Some Skinks have an innate knowledge of which jungle berries to use to salve bites and other nasty injuries.
Jungle lotus is one of the most potent of plants, and only a few know where it grows most regularly.
Jungle clearings and waterholes are where prey will gather; these are often protected by Lizardmen as a form of husbandry.
Lizardmen, especially Saurus, are meat-eaters, and so many animals are bred to slaughter and consume.
Insects are a large part of the Lizardmen diet; these jungles have both in abundance.
Skink potters are surprisingly adept, creating not just practical receptacles but often works of art.
Kilns are large Geomantic energy-powered ovens capable of mass-production.
Salt is mined. It’s an unpleasant and hazardous job - send in the Kroxigor.
When the Lizardmen need wood, the jungle provides.
Wood in its natural form is hard to work with, so the timber mills turn it into lumber ready for sale.
Found deep in the barrios, lumber from the jungle is bartered across the reptilian realms.
When squashed, certain berries and grapes make a pleasant drink somewhat above swamp water.
Once the draft is made, it is stored in great vats, where it will ferment, often sending Saurus into a groggy state!
When ready, Skink factors sell the draft in clay pots to others with a taste for it.
In times of war, the large lagoons in the Saurus caverns can be adjusted to gestate many warrior cohorts simultaneously.
Skink aggregators believe that cooler spawning climates found under the ground can produce better quality warriors.
The Temple Guard are placed in a dedicated barracks where they train and bask awaiting their sacred duty.
In blessed pools will the Slann bathe or stare - often for decades - until enlightenment is found.
A small gathering of cohorts, usually a settlement along the Geomantic Web in thrall to a more prominent temple-city.
A minor node on a smaller tributary of the Geomantic Web, comprising a lone ziggurat, often ruled by a later generation Mage-Priest.
Located on a lesser tributary of the Geomantic Web, comprising a ziggurat and surrounding barrios, and often ruled by a later generation Mage-Priest.
The temple-cities are where the Lizardmen spawn and live. They scatter the Southlands and Lustria, comprising of great pyramids, barrios and plazas.
All temple-cities are nodes in the Geomantic Web, but some are true nexus points - massive cities and major tributaries in power.
Spawning ponds are used for lower ranking Skink castes - the ponds themselves are small bodies of water, although many in number.
The hunter-caste spawning pools hold thousands of eggs that quickly gestate new Skinks, with a subtle temperature rise, at a Slann's command.
Elevated pools, closer to the central pyramid, are more likely to gestate specialist Skink castes and their bodyguards.
Located at the peak of the ziggurats are the Star Chambers, where the prominent Mage-priests ponder in their trance-like slumber.
Certain barrios in the temple-city are where Skink artisans reside, arguably the most important of which are the weapon-crafters.
The hatcheries are tall pylons that nearly match the peak of the central pyramid. Within their tips are nests containing many Terradon eggs.
Shrines to certain lesser or forgotten Old Ones are scattered throughout the temple-cities; no matter how insignificant, they are still highly revered.
Temples of the Old Ones populated by many Skink acolytes and dedicated Mage-Priests are found throughout the temple-cities.
The great pyramids and temples are normally clustered at the end of the grand plazas at the centre of the temple-cities.
Where Skinks come to show devotion to the serpentine Old One god, and warm-blooded prisoners are put to the sword.
The site of many, many blood sacrifices of Lizardmen foes to the satisfy the Serpent God's eternal thirst.
A great fall crests the top of Sotek's pyramid, but it is not water that cascades down.
Razordon-like, the angular protrusions of the ziggurat stretch out in mute augury towards the forked tongue of the serpent crawling across the night sky.
Warpstone is concentrated Dark Magic, which has the tendency to attract more of itself.
Precious Warpstone seams, once found, will need defending against thieves.
This small settlement is claimed by a rogue force.
This settlement is claimed by a rogue force.
A sprawling settlement claimed by a rogue force.
The mountain peaks of Parravon are known for their large bird roosts, but even more famous for pegasi.
Lower-ranking Clan Eshin rats remain apart from the other clans' rabble in hidden burrows that remain Eshin territory no matter what the dominant Warlord believes.
Unbeknownst to most - often even the ranking Warlord - Clan Eshin has their own outpost or den within the lair, where Eshin members gather to plot.
The business of secret murder makes the establishment of escape routes, secret tunnels and concealed hidey-holes a necessity.
The pit is where many of the Clanrat packs congregate in a writhing mass to eat and enact their own petty plans and downfalls.
Favoured Clanrats, or those that have clawed their way through the vicious hierarchy, have a place in the barracks and access to better arms.
Deep in the warrens are the clan armouries; heavily-guarded by Stormvermin, it is the first place the Skavenslaves ransack.
Should the things invade, devious tunnel design forces them to chokepoints, where Warp-fire emplacements scorch the intruders to death.
Ingenious back-tunnels allow the clans to move their rodents quickly through the maze-like warrens.
Clan Moulder-rejected Rat Ogres and others are conscripted and chained to key defensive junctions and outposts - their handlers unleashing them at trespassers.
Shrill alarms sound off should detection sensors be triggered by incorrect tail swishes; only those in the clan know the right combination.
Jagged, irregular, wooden and metal fortifications surround the largest and most important entrances to the lair.
The most basic way of generating power for even the poorest clans is through rows of slave wheels, where Skavenslaves are run to exhaustion.
In the piston house, Warp-steam driven pistons power the foundries, laboratories and feeding dens that ratmen society relies.
Skaven have quickly adopted the generator systems of the Greater Clans which use Skavenslaves on treadmills to generate power.
While energy generation is rarely a problem for Skaven society, power storage can be a challenge unless the warren has capacitors.
A Warpstone reactor is the pinnacle of Clan Skryre engineering, hence they charge a premium, as well as a hefty vassal contract.
Large caverns, close to the surface, are often used as workshops, where Skaven war machines are built, laboured on by thousands of expendable slaves.
Warpstone is sent here for refinement and used in myriad other applications. Warlock Engineers and Warp-smiths learn their craft here.
Warp-turbines cost thousands of Skavenslave lives while in operation; a small price to pay for the development of the infamous Doomwheel.
The warrens are full-to-teeming with ratlings and immature vermin yet to prove themselves. Survival in this environment is brutal, harsh and often fatal.
Nest-nurseries are where powerful or special pups are taken to ensure they are not eaten by their ravenous siblings, or indeed their parents.
While some broodmothers are vaunted, such as the bearers of Stormvermin and other higher-caste specimens, the majority are kept in filthy pits.
Established breeding techniques applied to specially selected feral pups is the first step towards rearing bloodthirsty horrors.
The Packmasters’ expert monster-breaking methods allow even the most tameless brutes to be whipped into veritable monsters of war.
Growth Vats are used in most Clan Moulder facilities, but more rudimentary methods can also be utilised to enlarge certain specimens.
Although Clan Moulder's Hell Pit is the largest facility of its kind, many Skaven clans have laboratories dotted throughout the Under-Empire.
From his raised platform, the taskmaster guides and directs the noisome hordes, setting tasks or mustering the Clanrats for war.
The overseer chitters at the taskmaster, who in turn takes his anger out on the Clanrats below - Skaven society as microcosm.
The screaming foundries are where the Grey Seers set their Warpsmiths and slaves to cast the vile bells of the Horned Rat.
The Clanrats of Pestilens are baptised in a font known as the Pox Cauldron; their pustules swell and their transformation into Plague Monks begins.
From the unholy pulpits the Plague Priests chant and preach to their diseased congregation - sowing animus, disease and hatred of the no-furs.
Within the fell abbey, the Plague Priests preach to the frenzied plague monks amidst the putrid fog of the swaying censers.
Where the Skaven lairs meet the sea are ragged wharfs on which many thousands of Skavenslaves are offloaded from one clan to another.
The under-docks are harbours where slave-barges, captured thing-navies and all kinds of commercial products from all over the Under-Empire are delivered.
Home to the bell-fleets - the Lords of Decay's great navies - these are hidden places, giving the sea-clans advantage over the others.
Skaven collect exotic creatures, but not out of curiosity. Clan Moulder will always pay a good price for new specimens.
Once hunted, the creatures are stored in pens and cages for spectators or potential buyers.
In such underground markets, factors from Moulder and other interested clans come to barter-trade for specimens.
While red rock is not as prized as green rock, it still has its uses as dyes for banners and armour.
Skaven dye-plants are arcane-chemical nightmares that spew out toxic waste in an attempt to create… something.
Hidden caves and tunnel alcoves allow access to the overground, where Skaven hunters can stalk their prey.
If no-furs insist on wearing furs, then Skaven should wear furs too-too!
Skaven gemcutters practice on what Man-things consider precious stones, for it is Warpstone they really want to slice.
Skaven sniff out gold, and will excavate out of spite, knowing Man-things and Dwarf-things crave it.
Although they have no use for it themselves, Skaven purposely mine gold purely to inconvenience the other races.
Skavenslaves are sent to excavate iron seams - they will labour until exhaustion.
Metal-working is known to only a few clans, while others scavenge or barter for forged weapons.
Weird-stone not Warpstone! Smooth and lined, but some warlords like it…
Clan Skryre has cutting machines that can slice through stone… and limbs.
Some Skaven adepts are skilled at carving; warlords will patronise them in order to sell their services on for their own profit or status.
There are few herbs growing underground, so some Skaven scavenge for plants above it.
Alchemy has always been an area in which Skaven have excelled, having an innate willingness to experiment combined with little worry for personal risk…
Pastures? Underground mud-yards where mewling meat-things are kept ready for slaughter.
Skaven factory farms are hellish places where half-formed things are bred to feed the masses.
Larger factory farms are more than mere underground pastures – they provide food on an industrial scale.
Ratmen pots are far from the aesthetically-pleasing pieces of other races: they are scraggy, untidy mass-produced.
Kilns are large Warpfire-powered ovens capable of mass-production.
Salt is mined. It’s an unpleasant and hazardous job - send in the slaves!
Clan Eshin has a tunnel network that reaches into the far east, of which they bring powders coveted by the other clans.
Warpstone-enhanced lumber is always needed in the Under-Empire.
Wood in its natural form is hard to work with, so the timber mills turn it into lumber ready for sale.
Underground lumber yards, held under by clans and their factors, where goods are exchanged for many Warptokens.
Squashing sour fruits creates an intoxicating drink better than Skavenbrew, yes-yes!
Factors will store the fruit brew and let it ferment, like the Beard-things do with grains.
Clan factors will then sell the brew far and wide, often lacing it with Warpstone essence for those who can afford the price.
The worst pieces of broken swag scavenged from battlefields above and below, is thrown into the trash hole and fought over by the Skavenslaves.
Scavenge-piles are where the useful accoutrements claimed and stolen by the clans after battle are placed for its champions to scour.
The scrap heap is made from the most valuable items scavenged from the over-worlds of the Man-things, Elf-things and Beard-things.
Packs of Skaven gather in smaller burrows often used as staging areas where clans make ready to burst forth.
Usually owned by a dominant clan, these places are much larger nests linked by an impenetrable maze of tunnels.
The teeming tunnel networks of warrens do not just sprawl underground, but can riddle entire mountains and chasm walls as well.
Giant corridors and endless passageways run through these decadent Skaven hubs, where the ratmen mobilise in unimaginably vast numbers.
Skaven cities sprawl beneath the ground like swollen ulcers, with other races' ruins shamelessly usurped into their erratic architecture.
The foetid, shambolic temple is a maze of tunnels that all lead to the Altar of the Great Horned One.
Weapon burrows, where combustible Skryre techno-weapons are stored, are not jealously guarded because if incompetently handled the user will quickly perish.
For logistical reasons, Skaven clans have arsenals of their most successful and 'reliable' weaponry, kept secure with arcane locks.
The pure, unfiltered darkness oozing from this altar is enough to give even the hardest warrior pause.
The capital Reiksfort - home of the imperious order of the Reiksguard.
The Emperor's palace is the grandest edifice in Altdorf - home to the Altdorf Princes of old.
This Bretonnian outpost in conquered Altdorf has been given over to the ruling duke.
Palace of the Eternal Emperor, seat of the von Carsteins now and forever.
Etched in barely decipherable runic Khazalid, timeworn Runestones chronicle Karak Zorn’s ancient and tumultuous past.
Anaerion himself once sat upon the throne at Tor Anlec, making the city a focal point of Asur defences.
In Conalxa's shrine do the Chameleon Skinks give thanks to the Old One who preserves and enhances them.
Ancestral home of the Blood Dragon Order, an honourable martial order until Walach Harkon visited.
Arch-Necromancer Constant Drachenfels once imprisoned his victims within these crypts, so they could be tortured at his leisure.
Constant Drachenfels lived for over ten thousand years, constructing a vast library of ancient tomes and dread grimoires.
Those who visit the Chamber of Visions shall see what the Old Ones see: the many threads of the future.
Deep below the Tower of Doom, all manner of beasts are kept and … investigated, in the name of greater power.
Beneath the frozen glaciers of Karak Izor's peaks lie gargantuan lodestones of copper ore that lend this proud Dwarfhold its name.
Beneath Karak Izor’s frozen peaks, the Skaven exploit its massive copper ore deposits for the nastier weapons in their arsenal.
Spawning pools defiled by Clan Pestilens; the half-formed creatures that emerge make for easy pickings.
The sea-faring High Elves of Cothique built grand edifices into the cliffsides, creating palatial underground cities.
The Druchii give praise to the God of Smiths, in the hope he will bestow the legendary artefacts upon them.
All the best places are ones you've nicked from other races and then made your own by leaving piles of poo and shiny stuff everywhere.
The Court Hall are where the Undead nobles, and living thralls come to play games of courtly intrigue.
Dark artefacts and codified writings line these chamber walls, waiting for someone to unlock their arcane secrets.
While the surface city of Karak Eight Peaks is grand, it is, underneath, in the colonnaded halls, deep underground where the true wealth resides. It is ripe for Clan Mors to take!

The tombs of the revered Dwarf kings of the Eight Peaks are situated even deeper than the vaults. If Clan Mors break the seals of the crypts, it will ensure their entry in the Book of Grudges for all eternity!

The greatest riches in all of Vala-Azril-Ungol are kept in the treasury, a massive chamber that once held the wealth of the Dwarfhold and its greatest relics. Its seals were the hardest to prise apart… until now.
The finest steeds for the finest Elves. So it has always been. So it will always be.
Not even the noblest of Elven steeds are immune from corruption.
The court of Avelorn is a great carnival, pitching silken pavilions in which Elves make sport and recite epic poetry.
Within the great plateau of this ancient construct is the stellar engine; the secrets of its construction jealously guarded.
From the safety of a fortified position, warriors fire destructive ordnance upon approaching attackers.
Mourkain is the ancient Vampire kingdom of Kadon, who once controlled the Badlands. It was superseded by the Strygos Empire, of which ghoul-infested ruins still remain.
Blimey, dats one massive pile of bonez!
While Khorne may not approve of using the skulls of those killed by others, this near-infinite supply will still come in useful.
A mass open grave is a macabre sight to most, but to the Necromantically-inclined it is a place to conjure martial might.
A mass open grave is a macabre sight to most, but to the Necromantically-inclined it is a place to conjure martial might.
Oathgold or 'Galbaraz' is the purest gold, mined from the deepest of deeps. Only small deposits exist, usually in remote locations.
The Dark Cultists studying within say they can see the future. To this end, they study tirelessly and without cease.
The dark tomes that are studied herein, and the vicious incantations practised can shake the very foundations of the world.
The Tower of Ghrond’s luxuries are of little interest to the Skaven, yet beneath its decadence are dwellings considered far more suitable.
The screams of Elves tortured for the Hag Sorceress’ pleasure have now been replaced by the howls, snarls and shrieks of mutant abominations.
Let its thousand lamps guide you to safe harbour.
An ancient tower clad in pure gold, constructed by the Lizardmen at the order of the Old Ones in an age long past.
While this tower was constructed at the behest of the Old Ones, it now serves only to amplify the power of their greatest rivals.
Far, far below Hag Graef, slaves toil in darkness for their masters' wealth.
The precious minerals, so desired by the Druchii, are prized from the rock by bloodied, blackened hands.
The mines stretch on, seemingly endless, with every shaft and seam another hazardous tunnel of possibility.
Nowhere in Naggaroth is less safe. One could lose much and more along the treacherous crags.
Gaze upon the majestic beasts of old and realise your place within the world.
From within, the Blood Queen unearths new and excruciating methods of murder.
The Druchii worship the brutality of Khaine above all, founding centres of agony in his name.
Down, deep in Hell Pit are where Clan Moulder keep their most promising and... foul specimens.
Even at these shallow depths, noxious steam accompanies the dreadful cacophony of howls, screams and shrieks of unspeakable things.
The deepest depths of Hell Pit are where Clan Moulder keep their most promising and foul specimens.
Within the Blessed Incubator, the beasts of Hexoatl are kept, ready for the Old One Itzl to leave his mark.
Upon the southern horizon of Hexoatl, on the eve of the equinox, stellar pyramids will rise above the jungle canopy.
The shimmering, healing Emerald Pools of Itza are truly a sight to behold; even cold-blooded eyes appreciate their beauty.
Under Itza, the Vaults of the Old Ones contain many secrets of the Ancient Enemy, and, some say, how to finally defeat them.
This palace is the result of years of back-breaking labour. Somebody else's, of course. Not mine. No, no!
A treacherous path, to be sure, but safety lies beyond to those who can navigate it.
Safety, friend. Come ashore; you're in the greatest city in the world, now.
These towering gates bar passage to anyone harbouring ill designs about Ulthuan.
Deep below Iron Rock lie its vast magma chambers, formed by great earthquakes in ages past.
The gathering place and centre of power for Clan Mors, where Warlords address their kin-lords.
The once beatific fortress of Mousillon is now a decrepit pile, but still a formidable stronghold for the living to attack.
Leering over the landscape, an ominous sentinel keeping would-be brigands in check.
The citadel stands as a deathly warning to any who would oppose Malekith's hegemony over the Druchii.
The creatures that take flight flock to the Shrine of Birds, the Old One whose essence resides within awarding all creatures that take flight.
All manner of questionable items eventually end up here. Buyers beware, however, as pickpockets relieve customers of their valuables almost immediately.
At the court of the Phoenix King, many come to petition Finubar and play their intrigues.
We will continue to empty the Elven palace until every slight in the Dammaz Kron has been repaid in full.
According to the Norscans, those unable to defend their valuables have no business owning such things.
The first of Nagash's great and powerful edifices. Even millennia later it is still surrounded by fell magic.
It is only fitting that the great Black Pyramid is under Undead ownership.
It is in Quetza where Sotek's followers are the most fervent. The ratmen should fear the coldbloods that emerge from these lairs.
The catacombs of this impossibly ancient city conceal treasures that are not of this realm.
Quintex has stood since before the dawn of recorded history. Within its vaults lie treasures beyond comprehension.
The deepest chancels within Quintex may very well hold treasures and learnings that unlock the past, and foretell the future.
The great hangars of Karaz-a-Karak are the home of its infamous Airkorps.
The forest of Laurelorn is home to a thriving enclave of Elves that refused to leave the Old World at the conclusion of the War of the Beard.
Skavenblight is the noisome capital of the ratmen - a sprawling metropolis and chief lair of the Thirteen Lords of Decay.
Skavenblight, the noisome capital of the ratmen, is the most infamous of all under-cities - a sprawling metropolis and chief lair of the Thirteen Lords of Decay.
Here the High Elves may give praise to the ruler of the Elven pantheon, Asuryan.
What was once a place of worship, reduced now to so much cinder.
Give praise to the Lord of War, and hope he answers with righteous fury.
What was once a place of worship, reduced now to so much cinder.
Kraka Drak, famous for its gemstone and silver mines, is so rich that an entire hall has been lined with thick silver sheets.
Skavenblight is the centre of all Skaven power, where the Lords of Decay meet to decide the fates of all.
The impossibly high tower reaches from the darkest depths to scrape the sky; at its tip, the Bell of the Horned Rat.
Skeggi’s original founder named it for his daughter, constructing this magnificent hall at the start of his second Lustrian expedition.
An Imperial sailor discharged for his drunkenness and thievery, Smithy won the noisiest tavern on Sartosa in a game of dice.
Positioned close to one of the mountain passes that lead into the Empire, Pfeildorf Market gives travellers their first taste of Imperial wares.
At the sunken palace of Tor Anroc the Hall of Charioteers is an eternal legacy for Tiranoc's greatest.
Tiranoc is a hard-forged diamond: a resplendent city of defiance in the face of would-be catastrophe.
In the City of the Moon sits the Temple of the Eclipse, its power reverberating whenever the two moons align.
White Lions are proud predators that roam the northern forests, who in turn are hunted by Chrace's warriors.
The Loremasters of the High Elves take great pride in their vast scroll collections.
Visible from many miles, the White Tower is the greatest sanctuary of knowledge in the known world.

One of the reasons Eight Peaks rivalled Everpeak in greatness was the colonnaded hub of the Underway, in the lower deeps. This was a key crossroads, allowing trade and military access throughout the Karaz Ankor.

Beneath the Eight Peaks is a key nexus for all tunnels in the region – a junction that unlocks the World’s Edge Mountains for any ambitious Skaven Warlord. Whichever clan controls this hub can influence the entire Under-Empire.
The Underworld Sea is a cavernous ocean under Naggaroth that allows Druchii navies to swiftly travel from coast to coast.
The once-great court of Avelorn now lies sacked and broken in the wake of savage Druchii terror.
The Temple of Mists is surrounded by enchanted fog that protects all of Xlanhuapec.
They say of Tor Yvresse that it is easily as grand as any Elven city of old.
By dawn's early light… does it call to the bosom of the Old Ones for their protection and illumination.
Some battles are fought over areas drenched in magic. The corpses that litter these sites are ripe for Necromancers…
Lairs of the dreaded Undead Terrorgheists are massive caves filled with the bones of their prey.
Restless souls are lured by Necromancers into arcane wells and tethered to others for ever more.
An unholy font of dark dreams and trapped spirits, used by Undead Lords to bolster their legions.
The tree-lined courts are where kindreds send their princes to increase their status through fine deeds.
The healing magics of the Asrai are among the best in all the mortal realms.
An odd assortment of standing stones have long held watch over Albion, enacting an ancient purpose that has long been forgotten.
These rune-bound Waystones of unknown origin have received a patchwork of venerations from Albion’s long history of inhabitants.
Cleansed and restored at last, the once-derelict Ogham Stones channel their considerable powers to serve your cause.
Sturdy walls ought to ward off smaller bands of foes, should they think to try their luck.
Warriors of Chaos patrol high walls, keeping watch for threats and overconfident prey.
The enemies of corruption are sure to tread lightly in the shadow of such a well-fortified redoubt.
The glory of Chaos is no better displayed than in grand, oppressive architecture and insurmountable defences.
A fortress must double as a monument to the Ruinous Powers, a dark cathedral of worship and corruption!
The walls that remain look close to crumbling, yet a thick fog of corruption still lingers here.
The Ruinous Powers feed on the fervent worship of their followers, prostrated at the base of their altars.
Dark coils of energy emanate from the altar's corrupted relics, seeping into the very land itself.
Warriors gather, swapping stories of savage conquest, while remaining ever vigilant and eager for bloodshed.
Some altars stand as little more than a broken remnant of the past, suffused with the unholy energies of Chaos.
New blood is vital to any army, as is space for the whelps to prove their worth.
Dark rituals call on the favour of the Gods of Chaos, to revitalise the wounded among the faithful.
Sharpened stakes protrude outwards, forming a perilous ring around hastily-constructed wooden palisade walls.
The altar's dark aura ripples and churns, carrying its influence beyond bolstered walls and deadly traps.
High, fortified walls form a protective bulwark, guarding against all but the most well-prepared enemies.
Chaos Warriors keep watch at all times, ready to signal at the earliest sign of the enemy.
The stronghold boasts an adequate garrison, and a bountiful stockpile of supplies.
Strong leaders guard the altar, organising its defences and the hardy warriors under their command.
The wails of Chaos Spawn echo from the cave, where creatures broken by madness and mutation bay for blood.
Trolls roam the land to the far north, warped and twisted by the malevolent energies of Chaos.
Corpses of past victims are piled high, a galvanising symbol to all under the banner of Chaos.
Every worshipper of Chaos is awed by this pit of bloody bones, a symbol of victory and strength.
A story of conquest is carved into a tapestry of skin, to remind all of the growing might of Chaos.
Every wall is lined with the skulls of the slain, inspiring every warrior that walks under their hollow gaze.
The tokens and trophies of war hang on display, a tribute to the glory of Chaos!
Every battle brings material reward, pillaged from the corpses of the fallen.
As enemy blood flows, bounteous plunder is sure to follow.
Thralls bring forth their former belongings, all destined for the hall of treasures.
Chaos Knights are most feared horsemen, charging into battle atop well-trained steeds.
The fearsome mounts of the followers of Chaos are separated in stalls to better contain their wild aggression.
Large stables house a numerous fierce steeds, known widely to be every bit as ferocious as their masters.
The enemies of Chaos cower at the sound of flapping wings, under the shadow of a roaring Manticore.
Chaos Giants crush their foes underfoot, spurred on by wails of agony and the unmistakable snap of breaking bones.
The earth rumbles around the cavern, where something truly monstrous must reside.
Many a tale is told in the south, of the dreaded Marauders of Chaos and their fearsome, relentless savagery.
The Marauders' return drenched in the blood of those too weak to stand against them.
Hundreds of axes line the walls, each with a thousand stories of slaughter to tell.
A malevolent aspect haunts this shrine, where Dark Magic thrums among the shadows.
Dark Magic floods the temple, as the Sorcerers of Chaos channel the gifts of their Gods.
Powerful, Ruinous artefacts line cold stone walls, each an object of fervid worship.
Corruption and magic permeate the air, as worshippers gather to pledge their souls to the service of Chaos.
The spirits of the dead seem to linger here, a functioning symbol of the strength of Chaos.
Archers fire from the tower in every direction, launching arrows and projectiles at enemies below.
This fortified tower is a beacon of might, and a warning to all that would stand against the Ruinous Powers.
The emissary quarters are basic and cramped; they must prove their worth to Chaos before any boons are awarded.

It's got to be five o'clock somewhere!
The beer hall is always the happiest place to be on any Airship, evidenced by the constant singing.
Why leave your post when you can have beer delivered to you? Surely nothing could go wrong…
With a constant source of beer at the ready, drinking on the job is so commonplace it's practically mandatory.
With racks installed along every wall, nobody can complain about lack of storage.
This cavernous hold is always put to good use, filled to the brim with provisions.
When battle rages and lives are on the line, ease of access is vital for the quick transfer of goods and munitions.
Huge, automated mechanisms load cargo in and out, speeding up the process tenfold.
This dummy looks a little worse for wear, but it's more than good enough for target practice.
A small gallery allows for more guns firing at once; it's efficient, despite the awful racket!
This large compartment has been reinforced a dozen times to compensate for the occasional stray bullet.
Where better for engineers to tinker away on their latest designs than their own dedicated workbench?
Flying machines take up every available inch of space, in various states of repair.
Construction has reached new heights of efficiency, allowing the most complex designs to be brought to life along the assembly line.
Basic propellers provide limited thrust, but enough to get the Spirit of Grungni sailing through the clouds.
Ingenious calculations and a little practiced tinkering have left the Spirit of Grungni with a vastly improved thrust-to-weight ratio.
Standing taller than an irate Ogre, these huge metallic blades carve through the skies with ease, utilising the full speed of the Airship's engines.
Nothing beats the roaring sound of an Airship's engines when the captain pushes them to their limits.
The Slayers rarely leave their workshop, preparing night and day to be transported to their glorious doom.
This vast array of weaponry has become somewhat of a shrine, where the Slayers worship them as symbols of their coming death.
There is no better use of an armed Airship than to sail it headlong into the raging tumult of battle.
More ammunition means more dead enemies and a whole host of grudges settled.
When the battlefield calls, a hasty rearmament is more than essential – Dwarfen lives depend upon it!
When smoke rises in the distance, the Spirit sails at full speed, answering the summons with all guns blazing.
When the chain of beacons is lit, the crew of the Spirit know that something is afoot... something requiring their urgent attention!
The Council convenes on all manner of matters, from lowly planning regulations to designing new feats of engineering genius.
Usually close to the trade depot, the Guild marketplace is a bazaar of grumpy, haggling, Guild factors selling their wares and services.
Despite relatively limited confines and heavy foot traffic, this overly-populated district buzzes with market trade.
Here, trading is overseen and regulations are set to send even the most studious Dwarf into a slumber.
The telling scent of Black powder lingers in the air, where a continuous stream of weapons are forged to outfit the Dwarfen infantry.
The Irondrakes spew vicious flames from their Drakeguns, forged by an expert in the foundry.
Every target is punched through with holes clustered around its red-painted centre.
The cacophony of the shooting range is ample training for the raging uproar of the battlefield.
Military colleges such as this help prospective Imperial soldiers take their first steps towards becoming gunnery experts on the battlefield.
Empire Gunnery School's are second to none, training the most elite sharpshooters of every generation.
Nurgle's power grows with the splendour of his gardens, which depend on special micro-organisms to ensure they stay fertile and vibrant.
The dead are left to decompose in a swamp of blood and entrails, offering their foul nutrients to the soil.
A whole host of deadly microbes sink into the land, feeding a rush of Nurgle's toxins directly into the earth.
A stinking mould stretches out around the bog, growing exponentially as it soaks up every ounce of decay from its surroundings.
Murky tendrils permeate Nurgle’s realm, strengthening his influence by spreading and secreting foetid enzymes directly into the ground.
Nurgle's influence stretches out into the world, creating new avenues of infection among the populace.
Nurgle's vegetation creeps ever further from its root, secreting a malodorous toxin that burrows deep in the brain.
The ground itself pulsates with Nurgle's influence, as sprawling roots of disease sink deep between rock and soil.
Vines twist around every surface, ensnaring everything in their path until it oozes with infection and decay.
The mushrooms, molds and moss of Nurgle’s Daemonic ecosystems release spores toxic to mortals, but intensify his domination over his adherents.
Lethal spores take flight, flooding the air with a deathly stench and suffocating all doubt from the lungs of Nurgle's faithful.
Fungal infections fester and spread, twisting the minds of the local populace until they bow in subservience, offering their gold as a form of tribute.
A deathly mould infects the minds of the living, encouraging even greater offerings to prove the depths of their devotion.
The warriors of Nurgle dwell at close-quarters, allowing disease to run rampant among their putrescent ranks.
A huge host requires a huge hall, decorated with the blood and rotting viscera of their victims.
Large stakes settle deep into the earth, forming a protective ring of spikes sharp enough to skewer any foolish would-be attackers.
Stinking corpses pile high, forming an ever-decaying barricade that grows larger by the day.
Bodies hang from towering walls as a warning to all, picked apart by the carrion birds until more corpses arrive to replace them.
Karak Zorn is the Dwarfs’ ancestral birthplace – their first city. Long-lost monuments of their ancient Ancestors line this restored hall.
The Knights of the Order of the Black Rose are shrouded in secrecy, recruiting only from among the local nobility and said to worship Morr and wear his symbols.
This ancient Cathayan pagoda harbours priceless knowledge on how to better control each of the Winds of Magic.
Once complete, this embassy will help to establish good relations with the Cathayan people. Until then, we must defend ourselves from the rebel forces that roam the land!
An embassy enables people to work together freely in order to push back the Chaos plaguing the world.
“Nowt but a big old tree!”
Seal off the tombs and ward them against the foul magics to which they have been exposed!
The Hold has been reclaimed! Now the long process of purging it of Neferata's malign influence can begin...
The Gallows Tree is said to be home to an unclean hag-Daemon shunned by her own kind. To those that please her, she divulges the foulest hidden secrets.
Reaching the Throne of Chaos is the greatest feat possible for a mortal champion of the Dark Powers, and a sure path to immortality.
Goblin dwellings are tidier than Orcish ones, if only because Goblins are less lazy than their bigger cousins.
The sun-hating Night Goblins keep to their lightless pits and cackle madly on occasion – or whenever they feel like it!
Foul-smelling fumes billow out from dark burrows, where the craziest Night Goblins brew the Mad Cap, bestowing both supreme bliss and swift death.
After a certain threshold, a loot pile becomes a hoard. Greenskins don't build vaults, but the next best thing – stash hideouts guarded by loyal boyz.
Only the bravest Goblins dare enter in those dark arboreal voids enshrouded with perilous bone-white veils.
The snarling and munching sounds are much more terrifying than those heard from the regular cages… and far more disgusting!
A towering citadel of infernal industry, relentlessly churning an endless stream of monsters.
With breath as hot as molten fire, the frenzied braying of Khornataurs chills mortals to the bone.
No one dares enter these eerily quiet grounds save the greatest of Khorne's Chosen, lest they face their doom therein.
Cultists round up local creatures – and people – to be infused with Daemonic energies, turning them into bloodthirsty monsters.
Monster-breeding pits and caves which will fill any witnessing mortal with revulsion and dread.
No Cultists serve in these monstrous spawning complexes, their work taken by brutish taskmasters chosen from the very stock they raise.
The underhanded nature of the Great Game dictates that, on occasion, Khorne's agents appear as the servants of another.
For now, subterfuge, but in the end, the world *will* be stained red with the blood of mortals, at the Murder Lord's vicious hand!
Think of Tzeentch's anger when He learns of double agents in His midst, doing the Blood God's hellish bidding and beating Him at His own game...

For Khorne and His servants, trade is a necessary evil to facilitate their true aims: to tip the world into eternal Ruin.
Such things are useful when brokering accord with other races, but the Blood God has no use for baubles – only violence, blood and skulls matter to Him!
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_dae_resource_gold_1}}
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_dae_resource_gold_2}}

Mortals, however savagely fearless, lack the intrinsic might of Daemonkind; they need external implements to even begin to balance the scales.
Larger iron-smelting operations mean better-equipped mortal fighters. Unusually, it's as simple as that.
Here lieth a military industrial complex of the heaviest metals and most raging of infernos.
Tusks?! Bones? Skulls. For the Skull Throne. For the Blood God's eternal glory.
Big skulls. Small skulls. Weird skulls. Skulls aplenty. Skulls.
Skulls for the Skull Throne! For Khorne!!
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_dae_resource_marble_1}}
Marble quarries make ideal ritual sites, and are a great source of sturdy building materials.
In dark, blood-soaked pits, slaves toil to harvest Warp-infused marble who seethe with silent scorn.
Even Khorne's most loyal servants, savage and wild as they are, require healing after a battle.
Certain plants produce powerful restorative tinctures that even the most zealous of Khorne's Chosen find useful.
The Blood God has nothing against herbal enhancements – as long as the blood flows and the land burns.
Like others of their despicable ilk, Cultists of Khorne seek obsidian for use in summoning rituals... and for tearing rifts in the fabric of reality itself!
Khorne’s Norscan servants, such as Chaos Marauders and Chaos Champions, honour the Hound, protect themselves and frighten their adversaries with armour of void-black obsidian.

For sheer weight, and therefore force of blow, as well as its natural sharpness, Norscan swordsmiths have found nothing quite so effective as obsidian, formed in volcanic fires beneath the world’s surface.

Ceramic pots can be used to store flammable tar, acids, boiling blood and other defensive siege payloads.
Walls and buildings clad in ceramic layers can absorb impact from all kinds of bombardment during a siege.
Ceramics infused with Daemonic energies are just as durable as the strongest mortal-made steel.
Ordinary salt can nullify all kinds of spells and enchantments – a useful property to magic-hating Khorne.
Khorne's Cultists have become experts at torturing victims with salt, either for sport or for interrogation.
Salting the earth is the final wound to the heart of a dying world.
These particular 'spices' have little to do with the flavouring of cuisine…
Workers in 'spice' production facilities need to wear special protective garments, lest the fumes make them as volatile as the intended recipients!
Long term effects' and 'substance abuse' are foreign concepts to the Blood God.
Blood wine is a staple beverage among Cults of Khorne. The details of its production are stomach churning, yet it is nonetheless highly addictive.
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_dae_resource_wine_2}}
Blood wine distilleries are a grotesque sight that would make any mortal recoil in disgust – unless of course they are already regular consumers!
Timber is a versatile and sturdy building material, appreciated even by Daemons, if only for its tendency to burn.
When other building materials are lacking, Khorne's hordes are ordered to stop burning forests and harvest them instead.
Massive strip-mining operations can deforest entire regions in mere weeks, fuelling the ever-hungry war machine of the Blood God.
Gnoblars don't play many games, yet the ones they do play are typically about inflicting injury on others – or each other.
Rotting animal carcasses and rusty traps are strewn around the Gnoblar Trappers' abodes, their smell overpowering even to their smaller brethren.
For all their haphazard behaviour, Gnoblars are an inventive bunch, especially when given copious amounts of scrap to work with.
The Halflings’ diminutive stature allows them to fit into their own cauldrons - a hearty snack for any Orc about to Waaagh!
Built from the ruins of the cold-blooded ones' city pyramid, these idols watch over the Bone Nose tribe and guard its fortunes with silent malice.
The Spotted Skulls tribe carved many sigils into the totems that protect their tribe from corruption of death tainting their lands.
Within the great plateau of this ancient construct is a monument to the Old Ones greatest failure.
Gork and Mork are coming.
If you want da biggest and meanest Boars, you go to da Iron Pig Tribe!
The shimmering, healing Emerald Pools of Itza now shine red with the colour of blood as Khorne's grip on this area is tightened.
Creatures that take flight flock to the Shrine of Birds. It is here Khorne's own flying Daemons meet these creatures and let their blood spill down to the jungle canopy below.
The Temple of Mists' enchanted fog protects no one as the Daemons of Khorne walk freely through it.
