A Knight and his retinue are sent to lay claim to a portion of this settlement for the Lady.
This district is claimed by the peasants of Bretonnia and their Knightly masters.
Bretonnians are not averse to establishing colonies beyond their traditional borders. Araby has long been a favoured destination.
In order to tear down civilisation, perhaps it is better to start from inside it?
The overgrown lair that is the Beastmen district will be the place where a settlement's collapse shall surely begin.
A Beast-camp within the very walls of civilisation will ensure it is destroyed from within.
It is not unknown for Norscans and other hardy folk of the Far North to wander down and establish outposts in allied settlements.
A larger outpost of the northern tribes, who have been granted an area of the city to skulk and fester in.
A colony of vicious tribesmen that even harbours the more devout and fearsome followers of the Dark Gods.
A hoard worthy of a true conqueror of worlds.
Battle-worn banners planted in the corpses of the fallen; the Dark Gods celebrated.
Be wary when you stare upon the symbols of Chaos, for such sights can pierce the very soul.
Accept Ruin and corruption into your black heart. There is no other way but down.
Among the carnage and the rubble and the lost souls, it is here that the Ruinous Powers erect their twisted monuments.
Be they men, Dwarfs, Elves or Goblins, flesh in all its forms can be found here, ready to be put to best use.
Those foolish enough to challenge the Dark Gods’ foothold in this world stain these ramparts with their blood.
The despairing faces of the damned stare out in warning to all who would dare enter this terrible place.
Nothing saps courage from the foe like a mighty wall of iron and corpses.
More than a mere graveyard, here the dead remain awake serving a master who is abroad for now.
This district is haunted – only the dead roam its silent streets.
This necropolis rises high into the skyline, casting the rest of this settlement under its ghastly pall.
The Dragon Emperor's presence is everywhere. This outpost is a haven for both trade and his spies.
Eastern districts, surprisingly common in the Old World and beyond, are where exotic goods are stored and exotic street food is consumed.
A larger district of Cathayan subjects, this area will be full of merchants, soldiers and many spies.
Legend has it the Dragons passed the secret of black powder to their subjects, which was then spread across the world. Within, the powdermakers concoct that very recipe.
While powder houses are located remotely in case of 'accidents', towers use height to minimise the risk to neighbours in more densely populated areas.
Designed by Nan-Gau's master War-Artificer, the Sky-junks are wonders of Cathay's military; logistical boarding challenges are overcome by tall mooring towers.
Convicts of the Dragon Empire are oft-sent to the Great Bastion. They are the brunt – the first of its defenders to face northern invaders.
Injured defenders will be sent to the Great Bastion's network of hospices, where monks practised in the healing ways of Yin work their magicks.
Shrines dedicated to various ancestors and the Dragons themselves bring a sense of being, and restore the Wu of any lingering Cathayan.
The temples built into the Great Bastion not only bring health and strengthen the spirit, but are blessed by the Dragons themselves.
The mighty pagodas that line the Great Bastion are powerful shrines, said to be in the vicinity of gigantic Sentinels that rest in the wall itself.
Watch Masts are small, incredibly tall platforms with only room for two sentries. They are positioned regularly and reduce the need for constant patrols.
The more Barracks there are along the Great Bastion, the better the defences and the lower the pressure on regular patrols.
Fitting accommodation for officers and their garrisons, allowing the soldiers to focus on the defence of the Great Bastion.
Larger emplacements that jut out from the Bastion's north side give greater views of the Red Waste beyond for a more efficient defence.
Command Towers dot the Great Bastion; they are the strategic centres where the defence of the wall is co-ordinated, allowing for greater focus of resources.
Great stocks of bamboo and hardy redwoods are harvested and taken to the Great Bastion's lumber piles to ensure a ready supply of blessed wood.
The mills of the Bastion are filled with the buzzing of saws, shaving and shaping the lumber for use up the wall.
A network of workshops and forges that span the foundations of the Great Bastion, fashioning weapons and siege defences for the defenders above.
The largest foundries are spaced several leagues apart but are fed ores and labour from Nan-Gau and other smaller cities along the Bastion's length.
At the top of the wall, at regular intervals, are the arsenals of the Great Bastion, each filled with the freshly-forged weapons of Nan-Gau.
Water points placed at regular intervals along the wall ensure patrols remain refreshed and alert.
The garrisons of the Great Bastion are well fed and provisioned to ensure strong defenders and more-able bodies man the wall.
Feast Halls are used when patrols from a far section of the Great Bastion reach another garrison. It's tradition that the guests are made welcome by the home defenders.
Tea is served high in the parlours, for that is where the officers gather to exchange intelligence, discuss patrol routes and other business of defence.
Atop the Bastion Pagodas are the Grand Parlours, where the highest-ranking officers meet – accompanied by their retinues – with their peers to discuss defensive strategies.
The Great Bastion has many gatehouses along its sprawling ramparts at regular intervals. Below each is a gate allowing ingress into the Dragon Empire when opened.
Standing Sentinel over the Great Bastion are tall towers festooned with flying lanterns and ribbons of warning, each one containing a lethal array of defensive batteries.
Citadels of the Great Bastion are placed every few leagues. They are heavily garrisoned and from there patrols of hundreds across the wall's causeway.
Strongholds are massive emplacements within the Great Bastion, containing thousands of stern soldiers and arrays of lethal mechanical and arcane weaponry.
There are fewer than ten Fortresses across the breadth of the Bastion, but they are strongpoints – cities within the wall that hold countless troops.
This Bastion lies in ruins. Only the architechts of Cathay could restore this bulwark.
Peasant horses are kept in loose pens or corrals. Horses are not common in such households, so the loss is devastating when the beasts are conscripted.
The stables of the Jade Lancers, are palatial liveries where heavy warhorse are kept in prime condition, ready to ferry their riders into battle.
Longma are said to share the blood of the Dragons. They are winged and scaled mounts, whose elite riders make them the most lethal cavalry in the world.
Only the Dragon Guard and their serfs reside here. Trespassers enter under pain of death.
Some of the most prized weapons within the Celestial Empire are kept within, especially the powerful Celestial crossbows of Kunlan.
A break in the wall, allowing for a rampart where gunner and rocket positions can be taken.
Reinforced areas of the wall that jut out allowing for permanent artillery emplacement, be they cannon or rocket.
Whole defensive sections of the perimeter wall, consisting of a powder magazine that feeds several levels of gun emplacements.
Easy to maintain and man platforms, placed above and slightly back from the wall, giving defenders an unrivalled view of oncoming attackers.
Often part of the wall or even placed before it, these towers contains several levels of platforms from which the battlements may be defended.
Tethered to the walls, these Sky Lanterns are well garrisoned by troops well placed to use height as an advantage.
In Cathay, labour is bountiful and life is cheap, full of willing workers to help raise the nation into a new era. The bureaus ensure compliance.
Larger, taller buildings require acres of bamboo scaffolding to surround the structure as they are raised.
Lumber is collected from nation's many rich forests of bamboo, ferns, redwoods and fruit trees. The wood is used in many things, including construction.
While the savage children of the north and west make time for war, the Cathayans make time for tea.
Landscaping is an art held dear by Cathayans, said to invigorate the Yin breezes at night, and so gardens of contemplation are located across the nation.
While under the purview of the Jade Dragon, the many-limbed bureaucracy of Empire flows with the will of the Empress' agents.
Developed in Nan-Gau, the forge-style quickly spread across the Celestial Empire by edict of the Jade Dragon, to ensure all of Cathay is bolstered by guns and cannons.
Magazines are buildings with thick stones walls, for within are barrels of black powder which require careful storage.
Rocket Launchers are used extensively in the armies of Cathay. The rockets are stored in great silos designed by Nan-Gau engineers.
Most basic goods, from rice to furs, to more common seasonings can be found in the bazaars and markets across the Celestial Empire.
Merchant Caravans travel across Cathay exporting local goods, and bringing back wares from across the provinces.
Larger settlements have whole districts full of myriad goods, peddled by strange and foreign folk who have come from across the world in strange caravans.
Cathay is abundant with strange – to foreign tongues – spices which are used in medicine, by apothecaries from across the world and to flavour food.
Opals, agates, sapphires and jade are mined in Cathay and turned into beautiful stones by the nation's skilled artisans.
The most exotic wares, from furs of extinct creatures to bespoke arcane items are found here, under the Moon Empress' glare.
It is the cities that fund the Jade battalions, but they cast their net far to find candidates before bringing them to the camps for training.
Dormitories are located throughout the province, housing Jade Warriors as they are funnelled towards their host city.
Here the full array of weapons and advanced training are given to ensure that warriors are as potent as required by their empire.
Stored with the tower is the collected lore gleaned from the stars and the movements of heavenly bodies.
It is from the observatory the Astromancers peer into the cosmos, the telescopic devices also channel power to the Wu Xing Compass.
At the peak of the tower is the Celestial Beacon. Once activated it can summon to life the Sentinels which stand watch across the whole of Grand Cathay.
When called, all must serve in the Dragon Emperor's legions. Even the most humble farmer or hunter will be summoned to the local conscription administrator.
The temples and shrines of Cathay are many, of which a majority are dedicated to the Dragon Emperor, ensure the spirit of his subjects remains harmonious.
Sanctuaries are places where the soldiery of Empire are attended by monks of healing, learned in the restorative arts, whose patron is Emperor Xen Yang.
It is through the grace of Quai Yin, the patron of archers, that the conscription fields of the Celestial Empire are full of keen trainees.
There are many shrines in Cathay to ensure the spiritual fulfilment of its people, of which a goodly portion are dedicated to the Moon Empress.
The lodges are for veterans of the wars. They are welcoming places staffed by widows and widowers, and funded by the benevolence of Quai Yin.
The docks are where junks and other cargo ships will offload their wares be they spices, grains, and other exotic goods.
The rivers of Cathay are the lifeblood of the Empire. Day and night, junks sail up and across, delivering people and cargo to the ports.
Sea ports are larger harbours often located at the mouths of the great rivers, where they meet the Jade Sea.
Small peasant dwellings clustered together, normally close to rice paddies, perhaps with a humble ancestral shrine at its centre.
The villages of Cathay fall under the edicts and censors of the Dragon Empire. They are mainly peasant homes, but some will have local administrative houses.
Towns are bustling settlements where nobles and peasants alike mingle and go about the business of empire, under the purview of the Dragon.
Cities are few and far between, but those that exist are teeming with life: thousands of subjects all ready to serve the Emperor's whims.
The regional, administrative and defensive centres of the Celestial Dragon Empire are sprawling conurbations that make so-called cities in the west look like mere hamlets.
Towns will often be surrounded by high stockades to prevent bandit attacks, and in the south, raids by the Monkey King’s warriors.
Using Jade symmetry, these walls are constructed in the Cathayan style with equal outlets and inlets for harmony and to confound the foe.
Gather the Acolytes. Begin the trials.
Only one is needed. The Dark God's chosen.
A keep of bone and brass where the the failed champions of Khorne and their exalted jailors are gathered.
An ominous bastion of blood-drenched iron, Minotaurs branded with Kharneth’s mark are lured here.
A fortress of eight curtain walls, embedded with countless skulls; its castellan: a mighty Bloodthirster!
In the dark corners of the keep you can hear the buzzing from the nests – do not linger!
Grandfather’s bastions are made from the same waxy material as the hives and nests of the Rot Flies.
In the middle of this crumbling fortress – this festering pit – squats a Great Unclean One waiting to be fed.
The Seeker Chariots surround the keep, constantly moving, corralling the spawn inside – for they are imperfect, and deserve to be ridden down should they stray.
These bastions have strangely-shaped corridors that perfectly fit the silhouette of a Hellflayer – spend too long in its passages and the flayers speed by, mincing you in the process!
Amidst the pirouette spires and mirrored walls, the Keeper of Secrets walks between the realms, stealing the most intimate secrets from the minds of mortals.
The Flying Towers circle the realms and mortal planes, only touching the ground to disgorge Tzeentchian Knights.
The bastions of the Changer rarely land, but then the Doom Knights only get close to the ground when they are chasing prey.
Great, complex, building-sized flying equations are oft-times the nest-lairs of the sorcerous Feathered Lords, Tzeentch’s most powerful servants.
The blood-drenched Obelisk of Khorne radiates the wrath of its master. Skulls must be collected!
An obsidian stone, carved with the eight-fold path, that constantly gushes blood which runs in rivulets down its dark surface.
A mighty pillar of skulls; a worthy monument to Khorne, and ammunition for his Daemon-forged cannon.
Within Khorne's temples, amidst the geysers of blood and pools of crimson can his most exalted servants be called.
A grand edifice devoted to Khorne, the bloody carnage that goes on within its eight walls being enough to summon the Blood God's most powerful servants.
A weeping menhir that constantly dribbles pus and excludes a foul miasma that fortifies Grandfather's minions.
If enough diseased bodies are dumped at the base of the blighted monoliths, then that will surely draw Nurgle's beast to us.
A gigantic, pulsating tribute to the Plague God; it crawls with carnivorous maggots the size of a man's arm that pupate into insectoid nightmares.
Nurgle's temples are oft the shrines of other gods, corrupted and decayed with the malingering presence of Grandfather's diseased children.
A grand manse dedicated to the Plague God – a home to His most powerful and favoured obese servants.
The Dark Prince feeds off excess in all its forms. Show Him dedication and He will grant you vigour though this unholy locus.
This phallic monument to lust rises high into the sordid sky. It will surely attract the Dark Prince's favoured pets.
A monument to the Princeling of Pain. Call to him and he will send the most debased of his young.
Behind its finely-draped walls and tapestries depicting debauchery is the inner sanctum of Slaanesh's temple, where the most exalted visit pleasure after pleasure.
Open the doors to the Cathedral of Pain and witness the further regions of suffering, the delights of agony, and the true secrets of pain.
This many-eyed azure column pulses with the power of the throbbing, evanescent flux.
A large prism jutting out of the ground that glows with a many-coloured hue and thrums with power of sorcery.
This monument to the Architect of Fate constantly burns with polychromatic flames – a sure omen that the most exalted of the Changer's servants are coming.
Tzeentch's temples hold no definitive shape and rarely remain in the same location. Thus they may be found in the middles of cities, or in the wilderness.
Great towers of silver and azure topped by eyes wreathed in flame, they are a repository of lore where the Feathered Lords roost.
A powerful locus is required to keep a Daemonic presence on the mortal plane.
An even more puissant conduit sustains Daemons that exist outside the Realm of Chaos.
Perfidious daemonic entities will not stay within an ally's settlement for long without devouring a few souls.
Bloody remains laid out into the Ruinous symbol of Khorne. As fresh blood is spilt upon the tribute, new Creatures emerge.
Before the altar, those that beg for the Blood God's favour may hear the howl, as back in the Realm of Chaos the Daemons of Khorne are unleashed!
Many gory sacrifices are piled here, until it is deemed ready; the shrine bearers are then summoned and it lumbers forth towards the nearest battlefield.
Wretched, diseased bodies – victims of pestilence and disease are presented as tribute. If the request is to the Grandfather's liking, then His children shall emerge.
A platform of rotting flesh, surrounded by a constant drone and buzzing of plump flies, will surely attach the attention of the Plague Daemons.
Here a great cauldron lies. Upon gaining Nurgle's favour, Plague Daemons leap from the foetid brew to join the host.
Only the most beatific tributes will qualify for Slaanesh's attention, their manner of sacrifice a secret that only the Daemons of Slaanesh know.
Upon the altar of lust will the vessels of desire entangle. Upon climax, it refashions into a Daemon of Slaanesh.
A shrine of mirrors – those who look upon their reflection with envy will emit a frisson of power required to summon the most exalted of Daemons.
Upon the corpse of a scholar shall scrolls of forgotten lore be placed in cipher. Then, the giggling is heard, as reality warps and the Horrors come.
To stare upon the altar of Tzeentch is for a mortal to lose his mind, as fate's endless possibilities unfurl and the Sky-Sharks are set free.
Stalking the labyrinthine passages of the Great Sorcerer's shrines are the ever-bounding Daemons of Tzeentch.
Those that walk the eight-fold path radiate with the power of the Blood God and speak with His authority.
For Daemons and fleshlings alike, constant martial challenges are the best way to acquire a penchant for bloodlust.
There are infinite paths to glory in Khorne’s eyes, but all are drenched in the blood of merciless slaughter.
There is no other way but His; all will accept that battle and bloodshed is the only true meaning of existence!
A mortuary with seven cells, in which there are seven tables, upon which lie seven corpses of the Seventh Ague.
A catalogue of knowledge about harvesting and utilising deadly diseases for painful ends keeps the brazen in check and fearful of pestilent punishment.
“Ahh… Gentlecreatures, Children, pretties… lend your ears to your loving Father, cease thy aimless chatter, banish thy banal burblings.”
Caravans of Nurgle constantly patrol the hovels like a travelling circus, except the entertainment on offer is disease, sickness, and death.
Away from prying eyes, the last vestiges of decency are abandoned in lieu of animalistic pains and pleasures.
This place ensnares the heart’s desires as easily as Slaanesh courts the affections of mortals with his physical beauty and charm.
An hour in a hated lover’s embrace can feel like an eternity here, as shrieks of suffering and ecstasy echo in joyous melody.
No mere whorehouse, this boudoir will send the patron on a voyage of ecstasy across the Six Seductions.
The flying patterns of these large, mysterious birds can be read to garner power through knowledge of future triumphs or calamities.
With the help of silver tongues versed in scheming and rabble-rousing, division can be used to prevent insubordination and treachery.
Its visions are cryptic, but the occasional Daemonic voice can be heard from its image, instructing in expert manipulation.
The cults of Tzeentch are myriad and multi-faceted. The aviaries of the ninth level are where the demagogues go to speak with their Daemonic masters.
They lurk in numbers to pull mortals into the walls, trap souls in mirrors, and devour the rest.
Those immortal servants gather on their infernal master's whim to defend Him and hunt easy prey.
A locus – a point in the fabric of the immaterial, where Daemons are sent to protect what their master deems precious.
Who would dare assail the hovels of a Daemon Prince? Nevertheless, it is prudent to keep watch over all which you hold sway.
Though appearing as a great barrier of stone and spikes, when one gets close the horror image of the calcified and impaled dead becomes clear.
A tower of brass and iron is made from Khorne's sacred elements and an icon that this settlement is now part of His domain.
In Khorne’s realm, such structures are not for execution, but to hang dead worshippers of his brothers slain in glorious battle.
Though the Blood God is chiefly worshipped in battle, his adherents sometimes place their victims' bones upon the ground to crudely mimic his symbology.
Flesh placed here shall be offered as tribute to Khorne’s three-headed Daemon-beast that tirelessly prowls his throne room.
While others keep gold in their vaults, Nurgle's servants tend to keep more infectious specimens in their most secure areas.
To his delight, it is certain that the stench of this biohazardous goop will reach the Plaguelord’s bubo-infested nostrils.
Any place where all manner of waste is left to stagnate – be it of mortals, Daemons, or beasts – Nurgle’s presence is felt.
Nurgle is ever the fiendish botanist; to emulate him one must create their own Garden of Blight from which disease can be harvested.
Every inhalation is an opportunity for allurement. One does not need eyes to succumb to the delights of skin and flesh.
Exotic spices and hallucinogenic oils entrance the mind into the highest of highs and the lowest of lows.
To the truest devotees of Slaanesh, the sense of smell can reveal symphonies of sensation that can entice the brain towards mania.
The formulation and distribution of the Slaaneshi scents will fund many a cult, as well as increase the wearer's ardour and devotion.
A giant arcane rod pierces the sky, attracting raw energy of the ether and rousing the attentions of the Great Sorcerer.
This pillar bears thousands of cryptic runes, appearing just as likely to be senseless etchings as oracular mantras.
To rise in Tzeentch’s estimations, one must succumb to His manipulations, and ascend His warped pathways that defy logic.
Inside the silvered spires of Tzeentch lay His vast treasures and repositories of ancient and forbidden lore.
Erecting a totem to the Blood God in his hound aspect will instil fear in the weak and lead the strong to your cause.
Grotesque figures with hatred in their eyes embody a constant readiness to fight, just as Khorne furiously demands of His followers.
Upon this great slab the commandments and edicts of Khorne are etched, expounding the virtues of rage, martial skill, and bloody defiance.
Hundreds of skulls are bound together in the shape of an even greater skull, its forehead emblazoned with the X-shaped rune of the Blood God.
A great scarecrow, packed full of rotten straw and a putrid face with maggots falling out the eyes. Nurgle looks upon this effigy and chuckles.
From a fleshy home within a gloriously bloated corpse they spread in all directions, transmitting Nurgle’s pestilence and influence across the realms.
Covered in boils and wounds, barely living fleshlings wail within a cramped, suspended cage, as living symbols of Nurgle’s power over mortal bodies.
Those drawn to Nurgle are attracted to this place by a different sort of sacrifice, bearing witness to a slow, disease-ridden death.
The serpent coiled and splayed in the shape of Darkling Prince's mark. All within its aura must supplicate to Him-Her.
The blindingly resplendent sculptures appear differently to every individual, taking the form of every formerly-living object they once desired.
A majestic standard towers into the sky, displaying to all the seldom used hermaphroditic symbol of Slaanesh.
As in the worldly realms of weak-minded men, here the Lord of Pleasure’s name is whispered seductively by Daemons and mortals alike.
When the Eagle's Eye stares across the settlement, all know that it falls under the Changer.
Reading animal entrails is the most primitive form of divination, but effective when performed by the correctly learned individual.
One can never know true power unless they delve into the darkest, most chaotic aspects of magic.
The ethereal shadows cast unto this apparatus do not inform the present, but foreshadow change in the future.
Harbours twisted by the mutating effects of Chaos, where the ships of the Dark Powers berth and disgorge their cursed cargo.
It is from the Hell Ports that the Plague Fleets of Chaos ply the seas in search of slaves and other prey.
Into the Eye of Terror and myriad worlds beyond.
To flourish, Cults require mortals, who in-turn require mortal accoutrements such as animals for meat and leather.
An outpost for Cultists to cull animals for meat and other by-products to fund their Cult.
In larger enclaves, where animal culling occurs on a vast scale, some workers are Cult members while others are oblivious to the true masters they serve.
Cults have many fronts to secure the funding they require. Dye camps and houses are often part of that.
Such outposts have a caustic air, and many dead workers, for the Cults care little for health and safety!
Larger institutions are run as profitable dying businesses, their workers labouring yet unaware they serve the Dark Gods indirectly.
Furs have value within the Cults, whose members oft-hail from the cold north.
Camps harvesting furs exist far from civilisation, run by the Cults to fund activities that are far more Ruinous.
A larger camp that can be distinguished from the more mundane versions by the terrible runes singed into the furs.
Gems not only hold great monetary value but may contain malign spirits and even… Daemons!
Camps and enclaves under the sway of a Cult that mines gems to fill its ever-hungry treasury.
Secret gem mines hidden even from the Dwarfs, looking for any valuable stone that will help fund their Dark God's machinations.
Gold opens doors even for the clandestine minions of the Dark Gods. Cults are often placed close to captured gold mines.
Larger mines require more manpower, but the rewards are worth the risks.
Mines that are far from exhausted will gain rudimentary fortifications and more slaves to harvest the riches within.
Iron ores are valuable for the Cults, not just as a commodity, but by the Cultists themselves to fashion weapons to be used in the inevitable rebellion to come.
Large iron-smelting operations generate more profit and assets to enrich the Cults.
Big mining operations are either fronts for Cults or hidden away far from civilisation.
Tusks hold value to traders and Sorcerers who use them in spells and potions – a steady income for any Cult.
Larger ivory operations involve the trade of tusks, often, but not exclusively, from the Mountains of Mourn.
Trading in tusks offers great wealth for shadowy Cultist backers; enclaves are where the mass stocks are stored.
Cultists operations around marble are usually fronts, as a certain expertise is required to quarry and shape it.
Marble quarries make ideal ritual sites, but also hold wealth the Cults can exploit.
Marble mills under Cult ownership generate profits for the Dark Gods, even if the workers are unaware of their true masters.
Perhaps surprisingly, this field is favoured by Nurgle's Cults, who are keen to infiltrate the burgeoning apothecarial industry.
Those dealing in tinctures and medicines have access to wealth and, more importantly, the wealthy.
The apothecarial resources have uses within the Dark Cults, both for wealth and as a vector to infiltrate the higher levels of society.
The legendary black ore, oft-ensorcelled with arcane power. Cultists mine it for trading amongst themselves and other nefarious merchants.
Outposts located in remote areas, close to mountains, seek out obsidian to fund the Cults of Chaos.
Large obsidian mining operations use slaves and Cult labourers to collect the arcane ore for trading and enchantment.
Cultists will take land from poor farmers for their own beasts of burden.
Larger farmsteads that come under Cultist ownership will quickly become corrupted, as will the animals that feed upon them.
Cult enclaves of farmland will see their livestock change; subtly at first, but by the end of the seasons, carnivorous cattle are the norm.
Pottery is like any other resource, and can be co-opted by Cults to fund their machinations.
Camps that churn out pottery for the Cults inevitably put hidden marks and sigils in their patterns to subtly corrupt their users.
Whole enclaves of potters mass-produce corrupted clayware for great profits, hoping to avoid the witchhunter's raids for as long as they can.
Gathering salt from the pits is hard, hazardous work, perfect for a Cult's lowliest peons.
Outposts to collect salt for a Cult's coffers are found in remote areas – deep in marshes or in alcoves near the world's oceans.
Enclaves of salt production keep the Cults funded. Such a mundane industry keeps the glare of the witchhunters at bay.
Often hailing from Grand Cathay, Cults that deal in spices are often aligned to the Changer, although that is not always the case.
Spice traders that deal with Cults must be wary, for they never truly know with what their spices are laced...
Large spice enclaves contain stock as valuable as gold and gems; such a rich commodity is used to fund a Cult's existence.
Simple camps that collect and store wood on the outskirts of forests are easy targets for Cult subversion.
Timber is a good way to fund the Cults of Chaos, for those woodsmen working for the Ruinous Powers are more likely to survive their forest trips.
Timber mills are a profitable business regardless of who owns them – whether honest merchants or shadowy Cult financiers.
Slaanesh Cults are oft-drawn to the sale of wines for obvious reasons, but the other Ruinous Powers also use the grape to fund their schemes.
Wine merchants in thrall to a Cult will sell their Chaos-laced wines to unsuspecting consumers.
Whole vineyards dedicated to the Dark Gods produce grapes with which to make wine that no priest would ever bless.
A minor rupture in reality that is, nevertheless, an opportunity for cunning Daemonic minds to slip through.
An isolated tower, where its Daemonic owner keeps the harvested souls until the day they need to feast.
There is nothing within these sullen shacks but corpses; victims dedicated to the Ruinous Powers, now carrion for the Furies.
The fabric that separates the Realm of Chaos from the mortal plane has been breached. Daemonic entities gather, ready to flood the world.
In the darkness rise the bastions of the Daemons, the retreats of the greater servants to the Dark Gods.
This hamlet is festooned with runes and symbols of the Dark Gods. Whether the populace are willing or reluctant worshippers is irrelevant.
A large fissure in the mortal plane, through which the Winds of Magic blow a gale and allow Daemons to spread beyond their immortal confines.
Great keeps dedicated to the Ruinous Powers, populated by screaming, wrathful and calculating Daemonic servants.
A larger village or town marked by Chaos and under the auspices of the Daemon Prince. Only the strongest will survive within its streets.
An opening upon the world's skin which refuses to heal – an infernal gate through which Daemons shall pass.
The great fortresses of Chaos are testament to the Ruinous Powers and home to all manner of cursed tributes and glorifying acts.
Chaos Bastions dot the northern wastes, although there are many instances of castles in the south becoming dedicated to the Ruinous Powers.
The walls separating reality have collapsed; an opening of this magnitude will draw a vast Daemonic host that even an Everchosen will struggle to command.
It is from the Chaos Dreadholds that the most exalted of Daemons launch their hateful attacks on mortal and immortal enemies alike.
The ultimate stronghold of the Daemon Princes, Be'lakor was the first to be awarded a fastness of his own, but he was not the last.
An isolated tower, where its Daemonic owner keeps the harvested souls until the day they need to feast.
In the darkness rise the bastions of the Daemons, the retreats of the greater servants to the Dark Gods.
Great keeps dedicated to the Ruinous Powers, populated by screaming, wrathful and calculating Daemonic servants.
Khorne’s gaze is ever drawn to places where gory displays of martial skill are facilitated, however unassuming such places may be.
With little space to keep a stable footing while surrounded by deadly puddles of lava, this makes for an ideal duelling ground.
Upon the Crucible shall the Blood God's champions be tested, and favour bestowed.
There is nothing subtle about a barbed enclosure where many warriors may enter, but only one leaves alive!
The ultimate theatre of death, where dismemberment, disembowelment, and death are commonplace, and spectators can become participants in an instant.
The dispensaries of Nurgle's Plague Doctors are often concealed as places for mortal healing, yet the opposite fate awaits its patients.
Nurgle welcomes all beloved lepers – not for healing, but to give them other diseases to spread from their disintegrating flesh.
It is not just old mortals who die here, but the sick and the damned, so the eternal cycle of life and death may be observed.
A macabre warehouse, where carefully placed carcasses rot and teem with microscopic life that is sacred to Nurgle.
A giant, living tumulus of cadavers reminds all that the Plaguefather’s power can bring any realm to its knees.
With mirrored walls of perfect sheen, each reflection reveals an individual’s loftiest self-image.
Fanning the egos of the beautiful and charming draws them to your side, in turn drawing Slaanesh’s gaze unto you.
Re-enacting the debauched competitions of the Dark Prince’s great halls puts the most desirable flesh on display for his sensual pleasure.
Slaanesh loves excess as much as beauty; the sight of bloated fools feasting to regurgitation pleases him, just as in the Circle of Gluttony.
A great dance hall full of salacious patrons where the Dark Prince's champions must do more than merely spill blood to find favour.
An inkling of future events and the Changer of Ways' intentions can perhaps be seen, but never comprehended.
If prepared correctly for trance-inducing incantations, one may receive perplexing visions and feel pulses of arcane power.
Though inconceivable, Tzeentch’s plans reach through time and space, observable by movements of celestial bodies recorded through eyes in the mortal realm.
In chaotic movement, there is order – just as Tzeentch may appear insane, but is an architect of fate.
An intricate Tzeentchian device of golden arms, orbs and azure gems that spins and whirls, channelling the arcane winds.
Now the Watchtowers will be seen far from Naggaroth's spires.
This murderous district is where strangers can measure their feeble lives in moments.
The colonies of the Druchii are as vicious as the Naggarothian cities from which they hail.
A Dwarf outpost will be a fortified compound, usually with a large brewery annex attached.
Especially within the Empire, many major cities have a Dwarf district where you'll find the best smiths and beer.
Dwarf colonies usually sprout up where rich mineral seams are discovered, so trade routes with Karaks can quickly be established.
Empire barracks and outposts have appeared in the cities and towns of their allies, such as the Border Princes, for centuries.
The Empire has districts within the settlements of lands as far afield as Lustria, Ulthuan and even the Far East.
The Empire has founded colonies on many continents. It has even established one to fight the Skaven on the Warpstone Isles.
Located on town walls, but also placed in deep fissures and caverns, using crew with keen sight to spot the cloaked Clans and prevent them from gaining purchase.
Scouts travel the land nearby, searching for signs of Skaven activity before reporting back to the lookouts stationed at the closest Sky Lantern.
Only elite scouts bear the sigil of the Dragon, turning savage vermin attackers into scampering prey.
Like bait in a trap, lurking ratmen will be lured to the Warpstone, and then discovered; tiny little souls of feeble nourishment.
Intricate and deadly traps surround the Warpstone, coiled and ready to spring at the slightest pressure.
Warriors patrol in a wide berth around the Warpstone, keeping a close watch for any Skaven lured in by its Chaotic, arcane energy.
Even in the coldest winters, it’s best not to let the night watch lapse; that’s when folk start disappearing.
What these outposts lack in warmth, they more than make up for in positional advantage, providing an unobscured view of the landscape.
Numerous hideouts carved from the ice are linked by underground tunnels, where patrols make regular circuits.
Devised by Gnoblars, a contraption made of scrap and some especially rancid meat – perfect for luring those sneaky rats!
Even a dull mind is capable of the occasional spark of ingenuity, a fact these clever traps demonstrate well.
The secret to drawing the vermin out is finding the right lure to entice them.
A Greenskin outpost mainly consists of a few lazy Orcs and lots of busy Goblins.
The loutish fights, chants and singing can be heard across the entire settlement no matter the size of the Greenskins' district.
A whole colony of Orcs is a hard thing to manage, expect several riots a week and incessant looting.

Situated in the heart of a forest glade, this serene grove is a beacon of nature's tranquillity and power.
Nothing to see here — just your friendly neighbourhood Gnoblars, offering a helping hand...
The Blood God's followers mark their bloody towers in the skin and gore of both allies and foes.
Such districts are where the streets run with blood, instilled with carnage and living, bloody nightmares.
The colonies of the Blood God are built from the charnel remains of enemies. A few allies will have 'given' their bodies as well.
In the intense heat, the hellblades are forged with the essence of the Bloodletter that shall wield it, while high in the rafters, Khorne's Furies roost.
This is where Khorne's favoured Bloodletters are wrenched from their mortal forms and painfully merged with their hellblades.
Across the blood fields, no wheat is sewn; instead, red weeds covered in gristle and gore grow in abundance.
The Warp-metal thudding of a Soul Grinder can be heard from miles away, shaking lands and hearts with a crushing terror.
On the crimson battlefields of Khorne's realm roam His greatest champions. Bloodthirsters never tire of war, so will always be found on the field of battle.
There will be blood and gore and death and skulls. It has been avowed.
In this terrible place, Khorne's warriors shall be called to battle for His Ruinous purpose.
The Blood God's servants build His Skull Throne one decapitated head at a time, to a soundtrack of the bloodcurdling screams of those brutally murdered for His glory.
Khorne's warriors may be restored to full strength if the correct litanies be uttered at the appropriate juncture in battle.
Blood for the Blood God!!! For Khorne!!!
Even the baying of the wolves can spread the Murder Lord's insidious Ruin across the land.
From hidden quarters, the Cult Magus orchestrates covert propagandists to spread teachings of his Dark God both profound and extraordinary.
See me, O Lord of Skulls, and accept this cranial offering, for it is made in the name of your eternal glory!\\t
“Step forth, Lord, through the eternity between worlds, and return to us in the here and now…”
To witness a Skull Harvester is to perceive a house-sized machine of nightmares that will strip a head of its flesh quicker than a mortal can blink.
Here, massive armoured creatures, part-Daemon and part-ensorcelled steel and sinew – the Juggernauts – are created.
A greater complex of foundries and machinery to outfit Juggernauts for mortals to ride.
Leaving a tribute to the Blood God makes Him eager for the next, and so He will quicken fate to see yet more blood spilt.
A towering skull totem brings more opportunities for Khorne and draws His more powerful champions, so they may also spill blood in His name.
While no one but Khorne may sit upon the Skull Throne, He will look fondly on they who fashion chairs of skull and bone in tribute.
As Khorne's influence spills across the land, great geysers ejecting clots of blood break through the ground.
Lakes and rivers fill with blood as Khorne's corrupting influence spreads across mortal and immortal landscapes.
And then the seas themselves turn to blood, as the Lord of Slaughter claims all…
Displaying your trophies – often the heads and flensed skulls of the enemy – brings the favour of the Blood God.
Acquiring trophies in ever-greater numbers requires larger chambers in which to pay tribute to Khorne and bask in His favour.
In the vaulted halls of Khorne's greatest champions, the alabaster skulls and stuffed heads of tributes are displayed.
In amphitheatres dedicated to the Blood God, slaves and defeated warriors are torn apart for the crowd's pleasure.
The arenas of Kharneth feature Bloodletters ravaging each other in bloody slaughter, much to the delight of the frenzied audience.
Gigantic brass arenas known as crucibles are where Daemons and mortals alike slaughter each other until the vast stadium floor is slick with gore.
Like all things in Khorne's realm, places and locations reflect the Blood God's mood.
This place reflects Khorne's mood, which is never anything but a growing anger up to an uncontrollable fury.
Khorne's utter outrage changes the very land – battlefields break apart, vents open and magma flows.
You hear the kennels before you get near them: hundreds of baying, hungry barks, signalling that the Warhounds are desperate to hunt.
While many Flesh Hounds rest in Khorne's throne room, gnawing on the bones of their victims, the ones yet to hunt await in their lair.
Amidst the dangling chained hooks and splattered walls, they who displease the Blood God are led inside, where they emerge the following night… changed.
Minotaurs already gorge on blood, but here the braying and yearning to feast upon flesh is concentrated into pure, unbridled violence.
The Altar is constantly fed with screaming victims. Beneath it, great troughs spew forth blood upon which the favoured Khornataurs feast.
Captured within the silo is Khorne's rage and fury at magic and those that use it.
In the foundry, blades are stacked in endless racks, and countless knives, swords and axes dangle down on chains.
Amidst the sparks and magma pools, canals full of flowing blood lead to a throne in the centre of the foundry.
Foundries within Khornate ossuaries produce devastating weaponry, ammunition for which is always within easy reach.
They lurk in numbers, to pull mortals into the walls, trapping some souls in mirrors and devouring the rest.
Those immortal servants gather at their master's whim to defend Khorne and hunt easy prey.
A point in the fabric of the immaterial, where Daemons are sent to protect what their master deems precious.
Much smaller and more docile than their distant cousin Karanak, these hounds have been bred over millennia to sniff out interlopers.
The harsh iron and brass-shod defences of Khornate walls are mounted with cruel barbs, screaming skulls and intricate, bloody mechanical traps.
For those who worship the Hound, armouries are sacred places, where weapons and armour are blessed sacraments.
The arsenals of Kharneth provide the Blood God's warriors with the choicest of blades with which to spill the crimson.
Here one is surrounded by weapon racks, and on the floor, deep grooves channel the spilt blood; these are the secret lodges where followers come to worship Khorne.
The collecting and fashioning of tallow is an important trade in a nation which spends many months in the dark.
Furs and leather are an prominent export of Kislev, which is renowned for the quality of its herds despite the harsh winters.
Carpenters of Kislev are used to working on the staunch oaks and pines of the forests, fashioning marvels from the hardest of timbers.
The stone workers are in great demand. Their most prominent customer is the Great Orthodoxy, whose alterations to temples old and new are extensive.
Gold is rare in Kislev, but what there is goes through the halls of the goldsmiths.
Selling necessities, stalls are operated by a lone merchants keen, and perhaps desperate, to attract custom.
Markets are found in many stanitsas, ranging from a few stalls to whole avenues of exotic wares.
The Grand Markets of the larger cities can rival anything seen in Marienburg or Altdorf, everything is for sale – from furs to exotic wares.
The Dwarfs that live in Kislev cities have come down from the eastern peaks to share their wares and make some coin.
Within the Merchant's Guild can be found the finest wares, sold to selective clients of the Druzhina.
The northern oblasts of Kislev are dominated by the Ungols, who think themselves of hardier stock than their southern cousins.
Ungol ghettos and enclaves are common in most larger Kislev settlements, even those as far south as Kislev City.
These larger tribal areas are found on the outskirts, formed of tents and other temporary structures – Ungols are uncomfortable within dense urban environments.
A larger, more formal area, where Ungol interests are promoted throughout the whole nation rather than merely the cold north.
The consulate is where tribal chieftains, Ungol Druzhina, and their dedicated representatives meet to decide how best to use their influence to serve Ungol interests.
Those taken into the Oubliettes are rarely seen again, including suspected heretics and even those who merely question the Orthodoxy's aims.
Whether you worship Ursun, Dazh or Tor, it matters not just so long as you worship within the Orthodoxy's churches and pay the tithe.
As the Orthodoxy's influence grows and spreads, it has begun turning the churches it has already usurped and upgrading them to Basilicas.
The cathedrals of the Orthodoxy are rich in grandeur and influence. More of Kislev's subjects abandon the older traditions and flock to its complexes.
Here the knowledge and secrets gained by the Orthodoxy are kept, away from prying eyes.
A small patrol zone, where black-clad Kossars keep wary eyes out for intruders and trouble.
From an elevated position, the Watch scan the frozen districts of Kislev's cities.
Criminals taken to the Watch House are subjected to the infamous Kossar justice – swift and brutal.
The garrison is where Kossar patrols will muster before taking to the busy streets.
The dreaded secret police of the Tzars and Tzarinas. Their offices and safehouses are many.
A temporary, defensive bulwark, developed over generations of repelling the incursions of Chaos.
Stone walls that surround the settlement, often imbued with ice and arcane wards if there's an Ice Witch nearby.
The lower ramparts of a Kislevian city are wide and squat – yards thick to withstand the onslaught of northern invaders.
The higher ramparts are slim compared to the lower-built defences but are much taller, and better able to keep foes off their slippery surface.
The Motherland's folk settle beyond the borders of Kislev, bringing with them Ursun's influence.
A Kislevite district in any settlement is full of drunken but fierce Kossars, trade factors, and even agents of the Ice Queen.
Colonies of Kislev are found in many places, including the Dolgans on the far side of the World's Edge Mountains.
The refineries of Kislev are constructed using knowledge garnered from the Dwarfs exchanged in alliances past.
In the smithery, Kislevian blacksmiths practice and perfect their art, of which the cannon 'Little Grom' is a masterwork.
By fully embracing the rule of its local Ataman and giving him control of its coffers, this city will surely aid his development.
Kossars are expert woodsfolk living off the Motherland, making a living from their huts deep in the forested tundra, and reluctantly leaving them for war.
The Kislevian term for a forest lodge, where Kossars gather after a hunt to feast and give thanks to the Motherland.
A large, often temporary barracks constructed to house the Kossars when called from their woodland haunts to fight for queen and kingdom.
It is Kislevian tradition to hang furs in the very caves and dens that once housed the bears that supplied them.
The bear stables, known as Ur-szalas, are furnished in a way that most Kislevian commoners would never see, let alone experience.
The larger stables are even grander, ensuring the most prized bear mounts are at peak condition when war comes.
Depressions in the oblast are where raiders meet to shelter their horses from the ice and winds.
A more formal gathering of the nomadic Horse Archers, moots are not a regular occurrence but happen often enough for the tribes to break bread.
A rare grouping of bushes and trees on the oblast, perfect for ambushers to gather and even lie in wait for prey.
While the forests are dense in Kislev, certain hallowed sites contain the best heartwoods and trees said to be blessed by Ursun's urine.
Where the oblasts give way to the untamed wealds, such places are guarded by acolytes of Mother Ostankya, who give leave for the Kossars to harvest.
Some forests are sacred to Taal and Ursun, where only Ursunite priests and Patriarchs may tread, or face the wrath of Mother Ostankya.
Before petty local matters are unduly escalated to more important Courtiers, they are dealt with in humbler surroundings.
More impactful Ice Court matters naturally require larger halls that are more fit-for-purpose to resolve them.
Envoys are occasionally stationed in important cities – particularly if the Ice Court feels its influence waning there – though such posts are expensive to maintain.
In more developed parts of Kislev, Ice Court matters will often be dealt with in grander, more centralised locations.
In instances where court matters are subdued, it is not uncommon for courthouses to house the Ice Court's ministerial members.
The grandest court in all of Kislev, the Court of the Motherland is where all matters of utmost importance are decided.
Only shrines sanctioned by the Great Orthodoxy may now be worshipped at. Those who ignore such edicts risk being accused of heresy.
Chapels once dedicated to Ursun, Dazh and Tor now fall under the Orthodoxy's purview, and every good Kislevian is expected to visit and worship.
If they feel their cause is waning, the Orthodoxy are not unknown take the costly approach of deploying missionaries in major cities.
The grandest religious edifices are the churches of the Orthodoxy; some are old, some are relatively new and built in a harsher architectural style.
Those taken into the Oubliettes are rarely seen again, including suspected heretics and even those who merely question the Orthodoxy's aims.
Large shacks found along the kingdom's dirt tracks which sell nothing but kvas – a drink 'enjoyed' by nobles and peasants alike.
Stanitsas will have a few Karczmaz – gracious hosts who open their houses for the drinking of kvas and Kislevian vodka in great quantities.
Gospodas are taverns and inns found in more established stanitsas and cities, where the varieties of vodkas and kvas on offer are truly impressive.
The less transient Ungols eke out a living on small farmsteads that dot the oblasts.
When farms grow, they will try to breed the prized steeds that are paramount for the tribal horse archers and scouts.
Larger, more permanent farms are almost always owned – but certainly not tended – by the Druzhina, the Kislevite nobility.
Along the World's Edge Mountains, and even on the borders of Troll Country, are these snow-bound caves.
A frozen outpost of the Ice Court, where the Ice Queen's chosen may find respite and even new candidates are discovered.
Kislev City originally started out as a small trading colony known as Pelzburg. It took some time for it to develop.
Tzarina after Tzarina spent more and more resource building up Kislev City to expand and prosper.
Over time, Kislev City has become more unique with its temples, bridges and city walls.
Kislev City propsered in the growing nation with its trade links growing stronger, even reaching as far as the distant Cathay.
Kislev City has never been taken by any invader, not even during the darkest of times, when Chaos waves came sweeping into the lands of Kislev.
Further out from the port, those ships in anchor send smaller boats to get their goods onto dry land.
Due to a lack of costal settlements harbours in Kislev are rare, but the few that do exist import many goods.
While Erengrad is the preeminent port in Kislev, there remain a few other substantial seaports on its meagre coast.
The Cursed City has been sieged many times, its people however are still not willing to move elsewhere.
Praag might be a dying city, plagued by corruption and mutations but it is still standing defiant in northern Kislev.
Praag has been rebuilt stronger with the Old and New Town reshaped many times.
Praag is very old and has a huge network of tunnels and vaults underneath. Great secrets are held in its catacombs
The Bastion of the North is a haunted and tainted city. Razed and rebuild over and over again, nothing ever managed to wash the chaos corruption away entirely.
A store that procures and sells the tusks of various creatures.
Tusks from far afield as Cathay and Lustria are bought and sold here.
Stocked from expeditions deep into the Southlands and the Mountains of Mourn, such tusks are hard-won, and therefore expensive.
Across the oblasts are dotted small villages and hamlets, led by Elders steeped in the heritage of the Kislevian tribes of old.
A stanitsa is a settlement about the size of a large village or small town, and usually run by Atamans.
Towns are larger Kislevian settlements led and administered by an Ataman and his deputy.
Settlements larger than a town are scarce in Kislev, but those rare few are run by a capable Ataman and his clutch of deputies.
The largest of cities are run by a council of Atamans, all with their own vested interests in how to make the settlement prosper.
The Guardhouse holds the elite Tzar Guard, formed to protect the Tzars generations ago, even though the Ice Queen now favours her own Ice Guard.
Upon the redoubts, the Tzar Guard stand sentinel, armed and ready to thump any foe that dares to scale it.
The Guardhouse holds the elite Tzar Guard, formed to protect the Tzars generations ago, even though the Ice Queen now favours her own Ice Guard.
Upon the redoubts, the Tzar Guard stand sentinel, armed and ready to thump any foe that dares to scale it.
Kislevians love to haggle, and the market is a chorus of bartering as seller and buyer seek to gain a few more silver dengas.
The merchants of Kislev are as shrewd as their Marienburger counterparts, especially those hailing from the port-city of Erengrad.
To counter the buying power of the merchant guilds from the Empire and Marienburg, the Kislevians have founded their own quorums.
A kingdom is paved to success by its roads, said one of the Emperors. Kislev should follow suit where possible.
Traveling east to west, across the Empire to Marienburg and Tilea, and even through the passes of the World's Edge Mountains.
A rudimentary defensive boundary around the settlement, from which its defence can be coordinated.
Once a stanitsa reaches a certain size or prestige due to an Ataman's governance, defences then become a priority.
An outpost located on a site with reverence to the Old Ones, most probably due to a Geomantic locus.
A barrio within the allied settlement, bustling with Skinks going about their business and perhaps even a spawning pool or two.
A minor temple-city filled with dutiful reptilian servants, carrying out the Great Plan under the glare of a Mage-Priest.
Unknown to the masses, the tides of war and diplomacy ebb and flow by the actions of a secret Imperial cabal of highly-trained killers.
A beached Black Ark leaves a Dark Elf contingent stranded far from home. A small force should be mustered to remove them; the warriors in question will gain valuable experience by doing so.
Bathed in the foul glare of Morrslieb in zenith, the emaciated figures contort into the alluring guise of a carnival.
Mementoes of innumerable roads threaten to topple over the entire caravan – a living, breathing travelogue imbued with the impressions of distant lands.
The mere proximity to this fractured wound in the continuum warps the steady flow of perception into a torrent of murderous hallucinations.
Most of the substances in this nightmarish slop coexist peacefully in malodorous ebullition, yet others gurgle a maddening, corruptive murmur.
Champions of the gore-slicked chambers emerge fully-fledged members of the cult, forever fermenting in ill-contained thirst for bloodshed.
The most ardent of these devotees descend a starless path where the lines between a paraded victim and their sybarite audience blur.
Like talons outstretched in eternal predation of the constellations above, the octad of star-crowned obelisks forms a grisly cenotaph.
A cystic outgrowth on the orb's Warpstone housing feeds the malignance barely contained within, causing its Chaotic innards to emit a sinister drone that penetrates the thick steel.
Crossed mattocks emblazon the liveries of these visiting Dwarfen masons, marking them as learned journeymen of Zhufbar’s industrious tumult.
The echoes of haphazard blast-mining explosions emanate upwards from the bowels of the earth, promising a lucrative cut of resources – just ignore the sinkholes and aftershocks!
Scattered throughout the mountain passes, solitary Dwarf Rangers keep watch, ready to hound unwanted invaders at a moment's notice.
As their designs are woven with near-peerless foresight across millennia-spanning lifetimes, the sudden appearance of the Asur is a cryptic occurrence to the younger races.
From a distance, this vineyard looks immaculate, its grapevines perfectly kept, almost as if sculpted into the hillside. It's almost hard to resist paying such a place a visit...
Cartouche-lined runes mark the entrance to this forge of Father of Darkness, their twisted truths privy to the malevolent descendants of Zorn Uzkul.
Here lies one of the virtuous few who quested long for the Grail at the Lady's blessed behest. Gather here and partake of his goodness.
Righteous affluence affirms the favour of the God of Merchants for the Wasteland's virtuous, leaving destitution for the morally weak.
Through heinous acts of worship, the influential gamble their souls with the Dark Gods for further power, riches and fame.
An old yet well-kept monastery perched on a mountainside. It appears this place is now used to spread the teachings of Myrmidia, and charges a fair amount to do so.
Savagely cunning, the maneater Tyrant recognises a simple truth: as intractable as their kin can be, Ogres still answer to the inexorable lure of gold.
To this shrine-forge come Vaul’s priesthood – Elven smiths, ritually blinded by their own hands, intent on gaining their patron deity’s shrewd craftsmanship.
Suddenly, somehow, the witless nobles of this place know things far beyond the capabilities of their limited intellects.
Nervously replacing his glass eye with a macabre apparatus, this oddly familiar charlatan makes even simple haggling a ghastly affair.
There are some husks of souls consumed by rage and hatred that will never escape the refuge provided by the worship of the Dark Master...
These lavender-cloaked enigmas intersperse their talk of kaleidoscopic eruptions of the flesh with alluring sermons of events yet to pass.
A small hideout belonging to the Purple Hand, there appears to be extremely strong magic emanating from this place, but for now it doesn't seem to be doing anything.
Here, Ranald's acolytes care for the poor and the starving, yet fund their charity by stealing from the wealthy...
The Scythes are unwelcome and distrusted for their brutality and unorthodox methods, but work tirelessly to root out all Vampiric threats.
A natural chasm deep in the coastal bedrock, which pirates have adapted into a near-impenetrable hideaway for their ill-got gains, and known to all as the Sartosan Vault.
Where sickness thrives, the followers of Shallya go, lured to society’s neediest by the goddess’ will.
From consorts and vagabonds to Lords and nobles, as civilisation has changed, so too has the Blood Kiss reached more in plain sight.
The Geomantic web thrums in oscillations invisible to the naked eye, birthing remarkable specimens from the glowing liquid of these spawning pools.
The magisters come on an ashen morn, following a sleepless night that delivered their ensorcelled towers to your very doorstep.
Operating right across the Old World, the Tilean Trading Company seeks to further its mercantile interests by controlling the docks where its trade ships harbour.
From the snow, the ascetics came, the winter seclusion having honed their knowledge of how to choke the life from Ulric’s greatest enemies – the Ruinous Powers.
The flowstone foundations of this yawning chasm glisten with recent wetness. The sloshing reverberations of the deep unknown are punctuated by... hisses.
Abhorring the ravages of time and wanton desecration that threaten their sepulchral masterpieces, the Necrotects are fiercely protective of their monumental work.
The greatest Warpstone deposits are torn directly from Morrslieb’s baleful orb, plummeting in fiery-green pillars of smoke.
This is where the Witch Hunters are based and the stakes are kept – short ones to extinguish the Unliving, long ones to punish by burning those citizens who've turned to the Dark Arts.
An interesting choice for the location of a Cult, but perhaps more understandable upon peering inside to see but a single crazed individual shouting about rats.
This outpost, reached only by Longship, brings fierce Dark God-worshipping huscarls to the allied settlement.
The Norscan districts houses Northmen and Norse tribes. Strangers are not welcome unless they are offering their very souls.
The most infamous Norse colony, Skeggi, founded by Losteriksson, is but one of many found throughout the world.
Sooner or later, the diseased remains of mortals succumbed to Nurgle’s Rot reappear as fleshy growths in his pestilent gardens – along with their souls.
The fusion of armour upon mutated Daemonic flesh requires the secretions of plants grown of seedlings taken from the Garden of Blight.
Hybridised plant life of Nurgle’s twisted design pungently decays within the swamp to create conditions ideal for something noisome and deadly.
Along these treetops rancid fruits rot into putrid organic matter, attracting Nurglish servants whose transformations into pupae have already begun.
The strange conditions recreated in these gardens mimic that of Father Nurgle's very own, aiding the progression of his lesser and greater Daemons alike.
Anything that steps foot upon this feculent pile of plant feed is soon submerged and rotting, for creation is always foreshadowed by death and decay.
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_nur_9}}
A pungently revolting final resting place awaits those whose decomposing body parts shall provide sustenance for Nurgle’s hosts.
A blighted outpost, accepted by allies as long as the poxes are kept within and not without.
To enter a district dedicated to Nurgle is to gamble with your own life, as few ever return unscathed.
Within the colony are lepers and victims – the ambassadors of dear Grandfather and His Daemonic servants.
A whiff of fever, a soupcon of pustules, and buboes galore – that's how Grandfather's beloved maladies are woven.
As pathogens spread, the energy and determination granted to Nurgle’s afflicted servants is given as a twisted solace.
The spreading of the Urfather's cornucopia of contagions to all living things is His servants' chief concern.
From the weeping sore of Chaos, the Urfather’s love shall seep forth, promulgating His rancid blessings in unknown forms.
From this dreadful place, the Urfather's love is propagated throughout the land by His ever-willing children.
We shall incubate the despair that feeds Him… until the pestilence strips our crops, and starvation bloats our bodies.
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_kho_cult_magus}}
By these words, the foulest of the myriad debilities that can infect the living shall spread swiftly through these parts.
