In the withered and diseased roots will the rot flies and other parasitic creatures of Nurgle make their nests.
Within the slimy bark, a great hollow, where a solid trunk once held, now riddled with disease and the minions of Nurgle.
A diseased thicket of swollen boughs, where the Plagueridden, champions of Nurgle’s lesser Daemons, gather.
As the copse grows it becomes a grove of infection, where diseases and poxes incubate, ready to be unleashed.
Blight Oaks are rare – massive sprawling trees, riven with labyrinthine root networks, said to be seedlings of the Great Tree growing in Nurgle’s Garden.
In the withered and diseased roots will the rot flies and other parasitic creatures of Nurgle make their nests.
Within the slimy bark, a great hollow, where a solid trunk once held, now riddled with disease and the minions of Nurgle.
A diseased thicket of swollen boughs, where the Plagueridden, champions of Nurgle’s lesser Daemons, gather.
Places like these are often settled by Ogre Maneaters, who are renowned for travelling the world in search of gold and meat.
The Ogre district in any settlement is a place of bubbling cauldrons, and large spits of meat known simply as "meat".
An Ogre colony is a camp within the allied settlement, where the cook fires constantly burn and meat is always on the menu.
Ogres oft-known as 'bulls' lurk here, playing crude games of chance and waiting for their guts to grumble, for hunger is a sign of food or fights, and probably both!
Spoils from raids are gathered and taken to camp, while weapons are stashed in a separate pile and picked through by the tougher Ogres.
The choicest of blades, maces and massive clubs are sub-divided into a special pile and kept for the Tyrant's closest mates – the Iron Guts.
Ogres oft-known as 'bulls' lurk here, playing crude games of chance and waiting for their guts to grumble, for hunger is a sign of food or fights, and probably both!
Spoils from raids are gathered and taken to camp, while weapons are stashed in a separate pile and picked through by the tougher Ogres.
The choicest of blades, maces and massive clubs are sub-divided into a special pile and kept for the Tyrant's closest mates – the Iron Guts.
Isolated from the rest of the camp, this is where the Hunter resides, his tent marked by all the furs drying outside.
This boulder-blocked cave is where the mewling scrawny baby Ogres are left to fend for themselves. They will be taken in by the Gorgers.
The Giant Pens need really tall fences, although most are not interested in escape if plied with enough fermented Stonehorn milk.
It is in the Boulder Fields, found on the slopes of the mountains, that the Stonehorns roam and hunt.
Every camp, no matter how small, will have a pot where meat of variable age and quality will be "thrown into da stew".
Larger than pots, these bowls will take carcasses about the size of cats and dogs to bolster the ever-stewing "lash".
A massive pot that will see whole cows and other grazing beasts flung in to make the camp's stew – hungry drooling Ogres surround it.
The camp boilers are for BIG joints, like whole manticores, or large cages of humies and gobbos – waste not, want not!
The largest cauldrons, ruled over by Slaughtermasters, can cope with whole mammoths – including the trunks and tusks!
A box or crate of Gnoblars are often carried to a battlefield where they are then unleashed to collect the valuable bits of scrap.
Ogre's love food, the size of their gut, and baubles such as gold – in camp you can always find valuables with the trader.
Successful traders have larger premises – often big huts, with patchwork awnings to store a greater inventory.
This is where traders and Hunters gather around ramshackle tables to sell their joints, meats and other spoils.
The bigger camps have so-called Flesh Bazaars, that reek with rotting meat and charred things on sticks – all for sale or barter.
Gnoblars get under Ogre feet wherever they gather, but are most concentrated in the 'Gnoblar Patch', which consists of rocky outcrops amidst mossy vegetation on the outskirts.
The sneakier Gnoblars lurk in the haunts – places far from the campfire's light, where even the Ogres avoid.
Gnoblars are prolific scrapers and scavengers. They scour battlefields, enemy camps and workshops, taking anything and bringing it back to their prized hoard.
The larger the scrap hoard, the more valuables are found. Gnoblars constantly scurry across the mound, picking out prized parts to exchange or use.
A tribe or camp's spoils of war are piled high, minus the Tyrant's pickings of course.
A larger pile of loot, gathered from victims, battlefields and sacking of settlements. The bigger the hoard, the more status the tribe gains.
In the bounty tent, the Tyrant's trusted Bruisers post their next targets and the riches that'll be bestowed on the Ogre who "brings back da meat!"
Larger camps have more-substantial bounty areas, where the infamous, notorious and potentially-hazardous bounties are posted.
This is where the Tyrant himself declares his most valuable bounties upon both enemies and those who are simply in the way of a good stash!
Camps will often be set up around the base of revered mountains that contain seams of valuable iron.
A mobile scrap-an'-Gnoblar-rigged version of the great ovens found in the more permanent Ogre settlements.
Another Gnoblar 'innovation' – a movable furnace scavenged from the Sky-Titan workshops which is then dragged from camp-to-camp.
Mournfangs are cave-dwelling beasts that live high in the mountains. They are captured by Hunters, dragged back to the camps and caged, ready for battle.
The largest and fiercest Mournfangs are put in the larger and studier-built cages for obvious reasons, as an angry Mournfang can really upset camp life!
A taller rock in the fallin' place where Crushers stand and 'dare' the rocks to fall on them.
A massive table, gashed and cut from previous meals. No plates are used here – slabs of meat are just dumped on the table.
Eating is a holy activity to Ogres. This is a modest tent where they can give sacrament to the Maw – farts and belches are acts of prayer!
A larger feasting tent, where more important Ogres and honoured tribal 'guests' can give thanks to the Great Maw.
The Tyrant's favourite tent for the best meals – a place to celebrate victories and to intimidate envoys from other tribes and races.
The largest meals are held at the Feasting Stones, where it is tradition that a new tribal hunter is selected in the post-meal stupor.
This is where the more mercenary Ogres will fling in their meat for cookin’. If a Tyrant is looking for Maneaters, he'll find them here.
The more worldly and richer Ogres tend to stick together, if only to make sure the poorer fools don’t nick their swag.
The most successful Maneater bands will keep their best and valuable pickings behind closed doors in a sturdy hut with ‘secur-eaty’ standing guard.
The tribe has room for another, so they best unpack the spare tent and steal some furs from an inattentive Crusher.
When Maneaters are not looking at the latest bounties, they gather at the table, looking for their next job.
This is where the hungry Maneaters hang, ready to work for food and riches.
Striding straight past the Recrooter'z Tent, this hut is where the really hungry and most-travelled Maneaters go to get their next gig.
A recently-dug pit with a few rudimentary shelters surrounding it, yet to be fully consecrated with meat. The most basic of Ogre camps.
Ogres are fundamentally nomadic, and so prefer to live in camps, often in primitive hide tents surrounding a large fire pit.
An established campground often used by the tribe, who will gather there when the mountains tremble or a large herd of prey is spotted.
Surrounded by a stone circle of upright Giant's teeth, these camps are sacred sites dotted across the Mountains of Mourn.
A large semi-permanent, shanty settlement, centred on an important or holy site that acts as a hub during times of great Ogre migrations.
Here bloody leftovers and offal are placed or smeared on the boulder or pillar in thanks to the Great Maw.
This is where the bloody gut plates of fallen Ogres are placed, before their bodies are thrown into the cauldron – for meat is meat.
The Gut Henge is a holy site close to camp, consisting of standing stones laced with rotting meat and the gut plates of the camp's most revered heroes.
The altars of the Maw, where the Butcher prepares the feasts and enacts the bloody rituals of their Hungry God.
A place for the Slaughtermaster to preach to the tribe as he cuts up joints, rips entrails, and seasons the meat with gut magic.
Mournfangs live higher up the peaks, in lairs that even Hunters are wary of entering for fear that the tables will turn and they will become the prey.
The enclosure is a large area of rocky pasture land where the tribe's beasts lounge, mate and often kill stray Gnoblars.
Here the Firebellies give thanks to their fiery god as they bathe in cleansing fire.
In the base of volcanoes which dot the Mountains of Mourn are the holy fire-caves which spit out lava: the blessed vomit of the Great Maw's son.
At the volcano's peak, the fat priests of the Fire God give thanks, for without Him the Ogre race could not cook meat.
With that many full bellies, the Ogres quickly learnt to weaponise their dung – creating trenches that could prove fatal if a trespasser fell in.
Moats of Ogre and Rhinox crap will surround particularly valuable and established tribal locations. Whole armies of foes have drowned in them before.
Ogres often settle in the middle of stone circles for religious and defensive reasons. Such locations are said to be blessed by the Great Maw.
This is where the Ogres gather to throw on all their spoils and as yet uneaten meat.
Here offerings are tipped from the Big Slab in thanks to the Hungry God, so that he may bless them with the belch of prosperity.
A deep yearning void, where meats and many other tributes, including live captives, are tossed, for all holes will reach the Maw.
Gnoblars get under Ogre feet wherever they gather, but are most concentrated in the 'Gnoblar Patch', which consists of rocky outcrops amidst mossy vegetation on the outskirts.
The sneakier Gnoblars lurk in the haunts – places far from the campfire's light, where even the Ogres avoid.
When Rhinox are caught, they are put in pens and 'tamed' to pull the scrap-launchers – the Gnoblars' favoured war machines.
An Ogre's love of gold comes closely after meat, as the Dwarfs know to their cost. It's collected and usually piled close to the Tyrant's residence.
Those Ogres who leave the Mountains in search of more exotic meats, gold and fame inevitably return with a full paychest.
Successful Tyrants are no longer happy with just a big stash of gold, so they charge enslaved Dwarfs, humies or even Gnoblars with telling them "numberz".
The more meat that's in the larder, the happier the Ogres will be, for they know a good feeding will come soon.
Having no meat stored up is not a situation any Tyrant wants to be in; keep a surplus and keep those bellies fat and you'll have content Ogres.
Only the prime bits of meat are kept in here, reserved for the Tyrant, his hand-picked Bruisers, and those he deems worthy of a reward.
Jetties made of driftwood and bone, where the rafts are tied. Often, they collapse if too many Ogres walk on them.
A rocky peninsula reinforced with scrap and wooden platforms that reach out into the mountain lakes or sea.
Natural harbours found in the valleys of the mountains are oft-claimed by the nearest tribe.
The collection of exotic fauna for private menageries is an established market – the curious will pay to see them.
Once hunted, the creatures are stored in pens and cages for spectators or potential buyers.
Busy, noisy markets of the rich and powerful, where buyers vie for ownership of exotic beasts.
Cinnabar, also known as blood-rock, is a mineral which contains mercury, prized by alchemists and dyemakers alike.
Blood rock mines are larger excavation sites for when substantial cinnabar deposits are discovered.
Usually situated in the same noxious district as the tanners, a dyemaker’s plant also spills out fumes.
For the picky Ogres that don't want to eat the fur, they take their meat to a skinner for, well… skinning.
More successful skinners ensure less meat is kept on the fur, so they normally get the hut.
Tanning, preparing the furs and leather for wearing, a technique stolen from the humies.
A gem mineshaft is for digging into the mountains in search of these precious stones.
Gem mines are valuable resources, especially if they have a high yield.
The Mountains of Mourn are full of gems and other precious rocks, if you dig deep enough.
Gold has ever been lusted after by men, Dwarfs and Ogres. Small mines dot the Old World, their owners hoping to strike big.
On discovering a substantial seam of gold, a small mine gets larger and needs fortifying against other treasure-seekers.
Once recovered from the mountains, gold is smelted into bars or minted into coins stamped with the head of Greasus.
Iron ore is a necessity in a world that craves weapons and armour. Smaller mines usually comprise a single shaft.
Iron mines are the most common underground works using techniques stolen from the Dwarfs.
Iron smelters process the raw iron ore, so it can be turned into steel or fashioned by captured smiths.
Bones and stones are prime materials in Ogre tribal society.
Though not as valuable as marble, granite is nevertheless a versatile material used in weapons and for many other applications.
Ogres have no fondness for marble, but the humies of both the east and west seem to love it, so they sell it to them.
Amidst the mineral-rich bone-shard soil are hardy herbs which Ogre hags can put to use.
Situated on the outskirts of the camp, behind the Ogre Hag's tent, is her garden of hardy mountain herbs.
The more delicate and potent herbs are found within the Ogre Hag's tent.
Volcanic ore is quite rare, and a precious resource for most due to the way it can interact with certain magic lores.
Items, such as talismans, made from obsidian often hold arcane power, and so those skilled in its manufacture are widely sought.
To be skilled at carving obsidian is to be skilled in sigils and symbols of power, for obsidian draws in the ensorcelled.
There are farms which are little more than tiny, muddy fields, on which graze scrawny goats or cattle with shrivelled udders.
Larger farms have more land and better, more permanent housing for the animals they keep.
Stonehorns, mountain goats and even Sabretooths are all valuable commodities in an ever-hungry kingdom.
Unsurprisingly, clay pits hold vast amounts of clay, a malleable material that hardens when baked.
An Ogre potter makes crude bowls and plates for meat joints and sometimes stews.
Kilns are large ovens mostly used by local tribes, who bring their crude merchandise to be baked prior to sale.
Brine wells are where solidified salt is mined. It’s an unpleasant and hazardous job, but perfect for scrawny Ogres.
Larger brine deposits need more intensive mining, meaning more pits that delve ever deeper into the ground.
These facilities are used for breaking down and grinding brine, as well as extracting salt from bodies of saltwater.
Strange, exotic – even sensuous – smells fill the air at this market.
Gathered from neighbouring Cathay, spices from foreign realms can be traded here.
Caravans from the east that are not immediately attacked come to trade, and bring with them exotic wares and spices.
A small copse of bushes and a few trees that break out from the harsh ground.
Abyssal mountainside trees, good for kindling and the Gnoblars oft-find a use for the wood.
Larger woods that cling to the mountainsides, home to both lumber and strange beasts.
A clearing surrounded by hide-awnings under which chopping blocks and pans are stored, where there is always a pot of stew or blood-soup on the go.
A large cave with a maw-like entrance; within, the Ogres establish a semi-permanent village.
Larger than most Ogre camps, this is a settlement surrounding a gigantic cauldron that constantly bubbles, and into which the tribe's enemies are usually flung.
Ogres stationed here are always on the look out for "funny stuff"... when they're not eating that is.
While the pokey Guard Tents see the sentries' guts rub uncomfortably close together, this larger enclosure has greater capacity.
The Guard House is close to the loot piles, ensuring its sentries will drop their meat and are out of the door at the first sign of trouble.
The old Sky-Titan casting workshops have been commandeered by the Ogres. With the help of the Gnoblars, they are fired up again.
Kislevian fletchers do not just fletch arrows, but can maintain and string the infamous recurved bows of the Ungol horsemen also.
Bringing an Empire-trained powder-mixer this far north is a risk, but this one is skilled in fletching arrows too.
Where the expedition's heavier and rarer ammunition is now stored to keep it out of unwanted hands.
With carpentry skills at a premium in the far north, the shieldmaker will be in demand no matter where he assembles his hut.
This far north, such workshops will be rudimentary, but with battles fought armour requires repair.
A larger workshop, full of firepits, smoke and rivulets of iron ready to be fashioned into Kislevite armour.
Nothing to rival the great smithies of the Gryphon Legions in Kislev, but this forge is one of the best in the Northern Wastes.
The reach of the Kislevian guilds stretches deep into the Chaos Wastes, able to clad the Kossars in the finest protection.
A small area within the boundary of the settlement where Kossars can train and perfect their charge.
Larger grounds staked out further from the camp, allowing for more hostile training manoeuvres.
Straw dolls are attached to wooden frames where the troops unleash their hostile attacks. The strawmen don't stand a chance!
A more complex training structure where Ungol and Kossar doctrines are meshed into one aggressive fighting style.
The training fields are dominated by a large compound overseen by Orthodoxy Patriarchs to ensure sanctioned regimes.
A building to recruit and train willing Kislevites in the Kossar way.
This larger military building has better training grounds allowing veteran Kossars to teach younger warriors the myriad ways to fight.
This is a compound within the encampment or settlement controlled by Kislev's fierce warrior class.
Wood is hard to find, for the trees are twisted by Chaos; the timber will need blessing before it can be used in construction.
The settlement is established enough for basic attempts to corral animals for their meat and hides, and even try to grow crops.
Rocky outcrops and pits are not rare in the Wastes, but the shaping and milling of such tainted stones is almost unheard of.
It is the Ungol way to gather at dusk, around the fire, then eat and drink to form closer bonds. Thus, the tribe will grow.
A large brazier is placed over the fire. As it heats up, chunks of horsemeat are thrown on to sizzle as folk gather.
The lodge is often found at the centre of Ungol settlements, where food is eaten and decisions are made.
Fill the stomachs of your warriors and fill the hall with merriment, then you will surely gain loyal followers.
At the centre of any Kislevian settlement of note is a grand hall where generous feasts are held to honour kith and kin.
Covert techniques of the Gospodar tribes, historic rivals of the Ungols, are bestowed upon Yuri's most trusted servants.
The few Atamans that have come north dispense their unrivalled knowledge to the agents of the expedition.
Within the synods of the Orthodoxy, Patriarchs teach martial lore said to be once practised by the Red Tzar.
Ungol elders hold their assembly within a ring of horses, teaching ancient fighting techniques for single combatants.
At the secret council, the Ungol Prince – or his most-trusted attendant – oversees the worthy from a journal Yuri keeps upon his person.
Valuable stores and provisions for feeding the expedition are placed here… and used to barter… if Yuri can bear to part with them.
With stocks so rare, any surplus is guarded in a hoard or stockpile. Such items can be bartered for income, no matter how meagre.
The settlement's trove of valued materials, including treasures found in the surrounding wilderness, are kept here. What is not used should be traded.
Built into the ground, with a thick door, the vault will keep the treasures safe.
Multiple vaults are excavated between underground passages containing traps to keep out trespassers.
The Ice Queen has despatched a few of her most trusted warriors to accompany the prince. They reside within this grand tent.
A shrine dedicated to Dazh, the Kislev god of fire and the sun. These are warm, welcoming places dominated by a large fire.
Tor is a god of thunder, and is worshipped as a warrior-god. His shrine reflects this martial nature.
Dominating the settlement, the Great Bear's statue stands watch, reassuring Kislevite folk that even though He is missing, Ursun is near…
Far from the grand edifices of the Orthodoxy, the makeshift chapel is closer to the Cult of Ursun's humble origins.
A larger chapel dedicated to Father Bear, but often with smaller areas of worship for Tor and Dazh.
A small campsite, where Kislevites can eke out an existence against the ravages of the Chaos Wastes.
This is a larger camp with semi-permanent structures, though still vulnerable to the predations of those that haunt the Chaos Wastes.
An outpost far in the Northern Wastes may be far from the Motherland, but it can protect Kislevian interests.
An enclosed, fortified encampment, that can withstand the rigours of these corrupted lands if well-defended.
A more permanent and defensible settlement, allowing its leaders to cast influence across the surrounding hostile lands.
The broken remains of a lost or destroyed settlement.
A small campsite, where Kislevites can eke out an existence against the ravages of the Chaos Wastes.
This is a larger camp with semi-permanent structures, though still vulnerable to the predations of those that haunt the Chaos Wastes.
A more established encampment, often seen in the oblasts of Kislev, but now brought to the inhospitable lands of the far north.
The ruins of a makeshift camp, now ravaged and open to the elements.
The expedition's limited stores of Dwarf-blended black powder are stored here.
The Kislevian name of the specialised stables required for the great war bears of Kislev. Once constructed, the massive mounts will ride into battle.
A totem of the Bear-God will bring order and reassure the faithful that the Motherland can expand this far north.
This hall, oft-made of sturdy timbers, is where the Ungol chieftain resides.
A keep is built upon stone foundations. It is more than just where the chieftain or Ataman resides, but a place of refuge.
A stern, stone building that radiates power and authority, with reliefs of the Great Bear worked into its walls.
Such great citadels are rarely seen in Kislev beyond its major cities such as Praag and Erengrad.
Kislevites are famous for their warrior horseback skills, and so look after their mounts as if they were kin.
Better appointed stabling to house the proud steeds of the Kislevian Knights that have ventured north with Yuri.
Bears came north with the Ungols. Creatures of pure honour that shrug off the corrupting effect of the Chaos Wastes.
This not-so-clandestine outpost, allowed to remain due to the ally's grace. Clearly, a weakling or a fool.
A larger warren of dedicated ratmen, ensuring influence to the Clan remains strong in this allied settlement.
This colony keeps the alliance remains intact, but can be easily cut off to wither if required.
An outpost dedicated to the attainment of excess. Visitors are always welcome to sample the delights within...
The Dark Prince's district is home to myriad Slaaneshi cults, each tailoring a vice to any and all who wander through.
A colony of deviants seeking one final flush of delight before the Daemonesses awaken to feast on their wretched souls.
Through the whorls of sweet musk and pigments of delicious excess, Slaanesh sends the most exalted Young to cavort, titillate and kill.
Here the fettered Hellstriders and Furies learn the true cost of the pact they have made with the Delightful Prince.
The cages of black iron corral the bonded Hellstriders, keeping them held until their hellscourge has grown or been gifted.
Deep in the Dark Prince's realm the grandiose stables cast aside their doors and out bolt Slaanesh's Seekers.
Found in the Vale of Creatures, it is in the darkest of groves that the Heartseekers – Slaanesh's best hunters – congregate.
Where the gilded chariots race to please the Dark Prince's desire for rapturous vainglory.
The Hellflayers ride hither and yon across the plains, tilling the realm by mincing the flesh strewn across the ground.
Here only the greatest and most driven charioteers may ride for the glory of the Dark Prince.
Behind the veneer of societal respectability, everyone – everyone – has a secret face.\\t
Temptation has many faces and myriad ways to entice and enchant the unsuspecting.
Like gullible fish attracted by the promise of a tasty morsel, ordinary folk are drawn to the Dark Prince... and onwards to their certain doom.
Take good care to draw thy circle true, for if the Gods prevail not...\\t
Have you never wondered? Have you never... wanted? Come closer...\\t
A whisper in the ear amongst a busy crowd; a book left on a library shelf for the unwary to discover. *This* is how temptation is sown.\\t

You can never have too much... and there's no such thing as enough.
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_kho_cult_teleport}}
Mortal and immortal desires are serviced here through the succubae handpicked by the Keepers of Secrets.
Lured into the grand house, many never emerge again. Those who do are free of worry, and seek only to return.
The High Seductress was taught by the Attendants to the Pleasure God – she knows of ways to titillate far beyond mortal comprehension.
Every taste is accommodated, every whim explored…
Those who join shall experience every possible torture, and they will crave it yet more…
To reach this place is to have already enjoyed every possible pain… But while pain is fleeting, agony is eternal…
Here do the followers of desire lap, drink and bathe in the liquor of indulgence; for it is milk from Slaanesh's own breast.
The feretory contains a slither of Slaanesh's majesty, made manifest for all his chosen to bask in its darkling shine.
Those who come within close proximity of this relic of the Dark Prince's vigour are forever affected by it.
A pool of liquid crystal with a serene surface. Yet should Morrslieb be reflected, it will churn and spill magic everywhere in its vicinity.
Those who look into this mirror will either see their bodies wither or made forever beatific.
The globe's surface remains cloudy, but it will occasionally trap mortals within its glass curves; the stronger, however, are gifted with amorous vigour.
The Marcher King disrespected the Princeling of Pleasure, and so was cursed to dream for all eternity...
Those who attend the Pageant of Pain will scream, and scream, and scream again, and again, and again, and again…
The opera never ends. Even when the performers' vocal cords have long since withered, the show must go on.
With the final dance it will be more than just one world that breaks, for beyond the veil lie countless baubles that shall shatter.
Before the agony comes the pleasure, the forbidden dancing, cavorting and singing with the Dark Prince's pets.
From pleasure comes pain, and those that feast upon it. The tormentors are Slaanesh's greatest servants, who steal the secrets that untether the soul.
The sweet scents within entice the rash northern mortals into the service of the Dark Prince.
To enter through the velveteen arch of this aromatic pavilion is to see where the Slaaneshi's favoured gather and frolic.
As the Drifting Castle transitions from the Realm of Chaos to the mortal plain and back again, the Alluresses make ready to perform.
The Bastion drifts through the silver-pink skies. Within, a feast of delicacies, and sat at the tables, waiting… are the hungry Alluresses.
Though the Soul Grinders are made elsewhere, this place is where the Dark Prince takes delivery of His machines.
They lurk in numbers, to pull mortals into the walls, trapping some souls in mirrors and devouring the rest.
Those immortal servants gather at their master's whim to defend Slaanesh and hunt easy prey.
A point in the fabric of the immaterial, where Daemons are sent to protect what their master deems precious.
Through this suspended vapour the followers of Slaanesh are empowered to more effectively see others for what they are, be it friend or foe.
A Slaaneshi mist hugs the base of the walls, sending those that enter it into either delirium or a comatose state.
At the very peaks of the mountains are the castles of the mysterious Giants that were overcome and eaten by the Ogres during the Great Migration.
High above the capital is the Celestial Court, the residence of the Dragon Emperor and Moon Empress. To behold it is to witness the true majesty of the ancients.
A hulking stone monolith that juts out of the snow-covered plains, where Chaos Champions and Ogres come for titanic bouts.
The only true neutral ground in the Realm of Chaos, the Court is where truces are composed and hostilities between the Dark Gods annulled.
Deep in the mountains of south-eastern Cathay lies a secluded temple dedicated to the study of the mysteries of Yin and Yang.
This grove was long ago desecrated by Vampires and tainted with their insidious corruption.
Trees seemingly rotten down to their roots yet somehow still standing, emitting a powerful mordant stench that invigorates the Undead.
The Ivory Road passes close to the Overtyrant's Hall, so he has installed a massive counter-levered barrier that is only lifted when tribute is made.
Of all the Ogres, it is Skrag that has a special connection with the 'Children of the Maw', the dreaded Gorgers – they obey his whim.
On the slopes of the Celestial Mountains, within the city of the Astromancers, is the to Grand Observatory – a true marvel of the eastern world.
Karak Azorn was the Dwarf keep founded in the Mountains of Mourn. It was cracked open by the Ogres who drank keg after keg of Dwarfen ale.
Found within the harbour, the temple is notable as Manann is not part of the Kislevian pantheon, yet is highly revered in Erengrad.
A tower of ice that rises above the city, it is where Erengrad's Ice Witches reside and has strong ties to Katarin's Ice Court.
Within the Old World, Erengrad's harbour is second only to Marienburg in importance – it is Kislev's trading hub to the rest of the world.
Connecting the north and south districts of the High City, it is surprisingly the only bridge within the walls to cross the mighty River Lynsk.
During the Tzarina's short reign, the Bokha Palace has been transformed; within the ancient battlements is a beautiful, impenetrable fortress of ice.
The home of the Great Orthodoxy, the prevailing religious institution seeking to control the lives of all Kislevites.
The holiest site in all of Kislev – the seat of the Ursunite cult, whose keepers resist the Orthodoxy's calls for ultimate control.
The opulent residence of the Empire's powerful ambassador; many state functions and political games are played out here.
A cursed area – a remnant from the Chaos Invasion, where the dead do not rest easy and convicts are banished.
The great defensive bastion which sits above the city. Below lies the haunted Square of Kisses, where Praag's armies muster.
A grand park named in honour of Magnus the Pious, within its landscaped boundaries are found the Celestial Observatory and the Academy of Music.
No one knows what will happen when the cogs of the Daemonium turn, but all agree that the lever to start the machine is within Khorne's reach.
The gardens of the Moon Empress are of an outstanding natural beauty, said to be more magnificent than even the heart of Avelorn.
In the centre of Fu-Hung the Phoenix Temple, a statue fashioned in the shape of a gigantic vermillion bird symbolically guards the Dragon Empire against monsters from the south.
The Druchii’s old prisons are put to good use against them, repurposed as great forges that churn out powerful weapons and armour.
Gatehouses are positioned at regular distances along the entire stretch of the Great Bastion, where occupiers can dictate the flow of travel through the region.
Towers loom above the Great Bastion's lofty ramparts, strategically located at key defensive points to help maintain control of captured holdings.
Heavily garrisoned and well defended, the Citadels of the Great Bastion provide adequate defences in the face of most moderate threats.
Spread out along the Bastion are huge Strongholds, where large garrisons of troops can hold out behind impossibly thick walls of stone.
Though rare, the massive Fortresses of the Bastion serve as a defensive bulwark for any occupier. Both heavily fortified and garrisoned, these structures seem all but impregnable.
Stones that represent the powers that might be, from which great strength can be drawn.
The corruption of such stones reveals a source of great strength, as well as great evil.
When the Feathered Lords gather, amidst the ruffling of feathers and the countless lies and vying for power, diabolical schemes are hatched.
The spiritual city of Weng-Chang is home to the Temple of the Jade-Blood Sorcerers, the greatest practitioners of the Elemental Wind of Life in all Grand Cathay.
Ogre legend has it this volcano is the offspring of the Great Maw. To feast at its summit is to give thanks for flame and ash.
'Ey, boss, this water's pretty good, but I've been thinkin'…
That's it, pay up, wouldn't want anythin' to happen to you out 'ere in the desert would we?
When traversing the vast stretches of the Khemrian desert, water is as valuable as gold.
Given time, even the harshest route can be turned to the pursuit of profit.
Deep below the sands rest ancient tombs long since forgotten.
…and out from the dark they stepped, sightless eyes gazing once again across the sandswept horizon.
Ambassadors from other nations are housed in separate compounds within the Great Embassy of Shang-Yang, for that is where the route west begins… or east ends.
Built from the minds of insane architects, the Inevitable City squats atop a multi-dimensional seam in the skein of time.
In the heart of the Paradox, the warrior-sages of Khorne work to unravel the arcane winds and bring about the end of all magic.
In the shadow of the castle, a windmill turned; its sails moved in the still air and their unclean breeze stirred the tattered flags of the dead.
Of the nine concentric walls that circle Nan-Gau, the Ninth wall is the tallest and most deadly – not that any enemy has ever breached the others.
The Dark Prince's baroque theatre, where actors perform a never-ending opera – within the rhymes that keep their secrets is the answer to the Limahller Paradox…
Only the Dragon-blooded may enter inner chamber, for there are secrets beyond… legends tell of the true origin of Yin and Yang.
Before me eyes the land itself heaved and pulsed, and spat forth mewling, puking and misshapen creatures that turned upon one another in search of further depravity.
At the Wrathgate every betrayer will meet their victim, but under its intimidating threshold it is the wronged that shall be handed the axe.
An outpost of loyal guardians, on duty long after their mortal bodies have shrivelled away.
Unearthed tombs mark out this area of the settlement as a Khemian district where the Undead inhabitants now roam.
Nehekhara's reach was long and went far beyond the deserts of the south, ancient colonies of Undead servants can be found across the world.
Royalty are buried here when their mortal bodies die.
Long is Tzeentch's reach. His eyes are everywhere, with agents in outposts on both the mortal plane and the Chaos Realm.
The labyrinthine alleys within the Great Deceiver's district are almost impossible to fathom.
This colony is not what it seems – humble buildings hide grand arcades, and impossibly tall towers are filled with ancient lore.
Inveigling their way into all levels of society come the liars and manipulators, all of them servants Tzeentch, even if they do not know it.
Then come the puppet-masters to pull the strings of the powerful, the rich and the useful, trading in lies and illusion.
Only those seeking what they believe is truth shall come before the summoning circle, where the Feathered Lords unfurl their wings and impart their wisdom.
Those who look into the well see the darkness, but the few who can look past that will see the colours… the bright scintillating colours.
Such archways are not attached to any edifices, yet they hold up the weight of dense magic – the wisps of which howl through its portal.
The great multifaceted stones which rise, taller than the monoliths of Albion, hold surfaces that shimmer a surfeit of bright, ever-changing shades.
Only through devotion to the study of Tzeentch’s unknowable ways may great minds truly open to all possibilities and outcomes.
Just as one falling domino turns into a cascade; from one unshackled mind shall come many.
Wherever Tzeentch’s supplicants gather, He is surely ten steps ahead. Sudden and unpredictable change looms…
The abyss we shall illuminate! Let its aetheric energy seep into the world to serve the Changer's bidding!
...and then I have a trap in mind that would be a joy to spring!
Slowly and surely, their Ways shall be Changed, and the Changer shall ascend.

It is by the gathering of His acolytes on this mortal plain that the Wind-lord's bidding shall be done, and His Mark made upon the Old World.
{{tr:building_short_description_texts_short_description_wh3_main_kho_cult_teleport}}
The acts of the Changer's thralls shall create the spark to burn worlds real and imagined.
Should Tzeentch think it, the blue fires shall smoulder then blaze and from them emerge his flamers, wreathed in the very fire they were thought from.
Burning blue, then turning pink-hot are the fires imagined by a fluxion god, and so arise the tendrils of the exalted.
So do the fires of Tzeentch burn so brightly that the servants of the Changer break free from the flames to scour souls lacking imagination.
The Shrikes gather in the highest peaks of the Chaos Realms, but will quickly descend when they sense lingering souls to consume.
The Screamers roam on magic's tides, gathering in shoals or flocks to hunt prey or attaching themselves to more dominant forces.
Tzeentch is magic and the Winds are drawn to him and his most dedicated servants, coalescing in whirls and seams where he deems it.
Through such a fissure the Winds blow strong depositing magic that the Changer's serfs can siphon for their own ends.
The skyrays of Tzeentch glide above and through this eldritch environment, seeped in magical energy, ripe for Tzeentch's use.
Tzeentch's agents are everywhere, withholding knowledge whilst, knowingly or not, enriching their master.
A gossamer lattice lies like a pall over society; it is in the secret hand-signals, the supposed random acts, and the murders that all serve Tzeentch.
When the Changer and his followers intervene there are always plots within plots, and schemes months, years, even centuries in the making.
Tzeentch casts his gaze into the eternal void and spies the merest glimpse of potential, enough to spawn his favoured creations.
Where multiple fates collide, the Great Deceiver creates a flicker of the probable into which he sends his lesser servants.
Plucking at the intricate webs that criss-cross reality, the Changer catches a full moment of something portentous and into it incubates his most exalted.
The Hidden Libraries of Tzeentch are secret repositories full of forbidden lore and countless spells of which even the High Elves are ignorant.
In the scriptoriums of the Great Sorcerer, Tzeentchian Daemons scratch out onto ancient vellum all that is and will be.
Scarce within the Chaos Realm, and scarcer still on the mortal plane, even the Lords of Change are ignorant as to what can be found there.
It is said that, should a thousand, thousand eyes be piled together, Tzeentch will see and send his Forsaken to welcome them.
He makes puzzle boxes that please the Changer and scatters them. They who play must solve them… or be granted Spawndom.
Home to Tzeentch and his mortal Knights hunting for knowledge and grimoires.
Dominating the sky are the Knights of Doom, streaming out from their Dreadholds to cull the foe for Tzeentch.
An intangible nexus that radiates with the power of the Great Sorcerer, it inflicts change upon they who come near it.
The reign of Tzeentch has just begun, or is it about to end? The Knights of Change are sent forth to ensure consistency is broken.
Since the Forge of Souls has gone silent, the Soul Grinders of Tzeentch must rely on this forge to enact their dark pacts.
See the convoluting ways, which ring and surround and bring confusion that will make Tzeentch's servants thrive.
In an unending maze, mortal and immortal alike shall be forever walking, and with each step losing their vigour – stolen by the Changer of Ways.
At the heart of the Silver Labyrinth stands the Silver Tower, but who lies within and how will he aid you, if at all?
They lurk in numbers, to pull mortals into the walls, trapping some souls in mirrors and devouring the rest.
Those immortal servants gather at their master's whim to defend Tzeentch and hunt the easy prey.
A point in the fabric of the immaterial, where Daemons are sent to protect what their master deems precious.
The Eagle’s Eye sees all, but cannot see everything at all times so is aided by places where his adherents can keep watch.
Tzeentchian walls form into maze-like barriers ensuring attackers are lost and those that try to scale them partly merge with the defences.
Reclamation of the Deeps in certain Dwarfholds can be difficult, as over time, many tunnels have collapsed due to fighting or lack of maintenance.
A large stash of Dwarf beer buried deep in the ground. The poor soul must've been forced to leave it here. No doubt he laments its loss greatly!
What appears to be an old inactive Doomsphere left by the Thaggoraki. If left alone it's likely safe, but to remove it would require the best Engineers to avoid detonation.
An enormous vein of gold deep beneath the surface. This will surely bring great riches once extracted!
An old Thaggoraki laboratory, long since abandoned in the Deeps. Perhaps there is something to be learned from this place, but beware, as corruption remains.
A collection of what appear to be broken Dawi-Zharr war machines. While they cannot be utilised in their current form, they could certainly be used for parts.
A Skaven burrow located deep beneath the surface. They should be wiped out without delay – it will be good practice for our courageous Dawi warriors.
An unfortunate discovery of a large quantity of Warpstone. Its corrupting presence is enormous and so the best Engineers will be required to remove it safely.
If under great threat, or annoyed sufficiently by the surface world, Dwarfholds can be sealed to the outside – much to the dismay of those looking to do business.
It's rare to find a Dwarf who will happily part company with their Karak – many a Dawi would rather go down fighting than see their Hold fall into enemy hands!
All manner of business occurs deep in the counting rooms beneath Dwarfholds, and tax avoidance certainly will *not* be tolerated.
The drinking lodges of the Dwarf Guilds tend to exhaust the local supply of beer, but they are quite effective business ventures should they become popular with the locals.
While most Dwarfs dislike the practice, your Oathgold can be melted down and used for more traditional needs.
Underdeep Trade Routes are dangerous, but in times of need can be extremely efficient – especially if your traders aren't stretched too thin!
Locked away deep in the Hold are the Grudges, a record of all treacherous deeds committed against the Dawi.
Deep beneath the surface lie the Deeps, the lower levels of a Dwarfhold. The Entrance Hall, the first thing visitors see upon arrival, is specifically designed to inspire awe.

Accessing the magma caverns in the deepest sections of the Underdeep is immensely dangerous, but there are untold riches to be found for any Dawi brave enough to venture there.

Dwarf mining companies are usually successful, partly because Dawi have a nose for rich seams, and partly due to their naturally small stature.
Guild Foundries can only be staffed by the finest Dwarf smiths and, as such, only a few can operate at full-capacity across the entire clan, but their output can be unparalleled, given enough time.
More than a mere graveyard, the dead remain awake in this outpost, serving a master who is abroad for now.
This district is haunted, only the Undead roam its silent streets.
This necropolis rises high into the skyline, casting the rest of this settlement under its ghastly pall.
This living outpost brings nature into the heart of the dirty urban environments of the so-called allies.
Usually found in the greener parts of the settlement, the Asrai keep to themselves even amongst allies.
There are only a few Asrai colonies in the world, but they can be reached via the Worldroots.
A mound of black soil and knotted roots, upon which fell spells may be cast, rises from the ground.
Darkling councils are gatherings of Bray-Shamans. Such a concentration of arcane bodies is bound to lure forth a Cygor.
Centigors can be found in the grassy plains bordering the deeper forests, where they try to outrun the elements.
Centigors are incapable of building their own shelters and so find hollows in which to rest and revel.
The strongest Centigors make their lairs in crude shelters or caves, daring any to challenge them for the superior residence.
Warhounds that accompany the Beastmen are kept in crude dens, where they are fed prey - both living and dead.
There are places in the blood-grounds were suppurating wounds burst from the ground and poison fumes belch from crags.
In the deep pits are kept Chaos Spawn, blessed with a multitude of gifts from their Dark Gods.
Some Giants will meander into the forests and make a large cave their home if it's not already inhabited.
A rudimentary shelter furthest from the camp's pyre, little more than an indent in the bony ground.
A pit hovel is a deeper rut, which, amidst the detritus, is where some Ungors choose to reside.
Burrows inhabited by Gors often have stinking and gore-infested hides around their entrances.
Pelts are placed on a grim totem, then taken into war by the herd's most fearsome warriors.
As the most powerful Beastmen take up positions closest to the fire, others squabble over discarded food on the outskirts.
The hag trees, which carry countless vile fetishes in their jagged branches, are natural meeting places for warherds.
Little more than a great pyre surrounded by gore-soaked tents, rude burrows and makeshift pens.
While not a permanent structure by any means, caves or burrows riddled with hag tree roots can house a brayherd.
Within the deepest cavern systems, the most ancient of tangled beast-paths forests of herdstones and pyres.
Minotaurs crave man-flesh the most. At the fire pits, manling meat sizzles on crude spits, drawing the tribes.
When prey is not plentiful, the meat larder is used, assuming its putrefying contents have not already rotted away…
To let the raging pyre lessen or extinguish is to proffer insults to the Dark Gods.
The tribe's Razorgors are kept in rough, makeshift sties that cannot hold them should they show their teeth.
Early following the establishment of a camp, Ungors are sent scurrying away to find wood for fires and other uses.
More than mere dedications to the Plague Lord, piles of putrid, rotten flesh are points from whence Chaos flows.
The Old World contains many altars to its myriad gods. When the Beastmen come, these sacred places will be despoiled.
Valuable metal blades - taken during raids - are placed in a mound or stood against the herdstone itself.
Once given weapon and armour, Gors go to the horned totem to be blessed by the Granter of Savage Hate.
Inside the Trickster's grove, his acolytes learn the many ways of mischief.
Where the followers of Loec guard his secrets from outsiders.
A hunter is nothing without his weapons.

Some pits are for throwing useless gobbos down, others have gold and other shiny stuff in them. Send in the sniffer squigs and claim it!
Taking mines from da stunties gets their beards in a real twist, especially when da boyz nick all da shiny rocks in ‘em as well.
Da Black Orcs don't mix with da other gits and prefer ta 'ave dere own fire ta throw stuff into.
All Orcs like to "'ave a go" at something big, hoping to claim not only its teef, but the hide too.
Goblins, being consummate tinkerers, have figured out that a great big saw is a way to cut up wood… "and yer mates!"
Smaller Greenskin tribes and gatherings rarely stay put, although they will seek out caves when they wish to keep "outta da way".
Orc and Goblin tribes are, in the main, nomadic, but will set up a large camp when the Boss wants to stop for a bit.
When the crap-pile gets too big and the horde of shiny stuff too large to shovel on a cart, it’s "time ta stop moving".
Greenskins like a good fort, it makes them feel important when they can shout and fling excrement from the walls.
The biggest and bestest Warbosses rule from formidable strongholds - the shattered Karaks of the Dwarfs.
Shamans live apart from their green-skinned kin.
Night Goblin Shamans tend to reside in hovels - mouldy lairs deep underground and surrounded by fungal patches.
A place of deep trances, where ghostly green images are projected above furrowed brows, and monstrous conjurations are invoked.
If a camp is "stayin’ put", gobbos will be sent out to dig a ditch around it as a basic defence.
Large stakes of pointy wood and other ramshackle defences of timber and bone are surpassingly effective.
A big wall is a good way of stopping an enemy from "gettin’ in".
The smartest gobbos can be right tools, in more ways than one!
A few Goblins have a base understanding of concepts such as physics - much to the disgust of their fellow Greenskins!
By making deadly war machines Goblins can grudgingly get the resources they need to make even "betta stuff".
No one truly knows when and how Dragon Ogres gather, but they always assemble on ground sacred to their ancient pact.
Where the Shaggoths go to invigorate themselves, standing upon mountain tops to bathe in the tempest.
A forge, deep within the Chaos Wastes, is no mortal smithy. Likewise the Hellsmiths hammering in the fire.
Within the hell fires are the Daemonsmiths, creators of fell and ignoble machines; grim chariots pulled by grim creatures.
Giants stride the world, mostly in an intemperate stupor. Those that wander too far north are enslaved and corrupted by Chaos.
Much like Warshrines, grisly trophies carried in the wake of Chaos Knights may attract the eyes of the Gods.
When a Chaos Knight's trophy haul becomes too large, a more permanent structure of bone and skulls is needed.
The preferred route of the magic-using servants of Chaos, an arcane vortex is for the damned alone to step into.
A tear in the fabric of the mortal realm from which Daemons and other horrors can - and will - emerge.
The Marauder tribes have no sense of place, wandering the northern wastes until drawn together by relics of power.
To prove their might they fight in the trial pit, from which only the chosen emerge.
The Marauders spar upon the bloody field, desperately hoping that the Ruinous Ones will notice and perhaps show their favour…
The tribes of the far north set up camps, not for sustenance but for worship and bonding under Ruinous scrutiny.
When warbands gather along tribal lines, they have likely been summoned by their Ruinous patrons.
Chaos' multifarious warbands range in size from small groups to veritable hordes.
When the omens are strong, the Unholy Legion converges.
Only Everchosen have sufficiently risen in power to command a true Warhost of Chaos.
The lairs of Trolls are foetid and disgusting; the further north they are, the more disturbing they become.
Stashed within this filthy lair are the trinkets and plunder from myriad battles fought in Ruin’s dreaded name.
By planting an icon in the ground, a siren call is sent forth that Chaos Warriors must heed.
Glorifying acts before Ruinous altars are summoning rituals that draw the most powerful of the Gods' mortal followers.
Warshrines attract the attention of the Chaos Gods, along with the mightiest of their mortal servants, for power attracts power.
A collection of infernal weaponry, some plundered from southlanders, some fashioned by the Hellsmiths.
Within the damned reliquary is stored the true weapons of power, culled from temples and secret places beneath the world.
Orcs like to eat, and they’re not choosey - game, enemy corpses and even their mates are all potential menu items!
While Greenskins will eat meat raw - they certainly have the gnashers for it - they do, in general, prefer to have it cooked.
Squigs are choice morsels – there aren't many Orcs that can turn down a roasted one!
Greenskins love to fight, as we all know, but there are more mundane tasks that still must be performed.
Even the Orcs realise that for wood to be a building material you need to do more than pick it up off the floor.
Sawn into boards, wood is ready for use in war engines, fencing, huts, and even just planks for spanking unruly gits!
The Father of Bears cares little for grand edifices, but in Kislev bear caves or standing stones are considered sacred.
Shrines to Ursun are rare, but temples are even rarer, with only the sacred groves in the capital and Erengrad known.
Wharfs are platforms jutting out of the water, allowing ships to be boarded easily.
Whether man-made or natural, a harbour is a place for vessels to wait out Stromfels' rage.
Large port-cities are strategically key during wartime, for they are home to its great fleets, both military or mercantile.
A shrine to Ulric, the God of Wolves, Winter and Battles and the patron of Middenland.
Normally found in northern towns and cities, the temples of Ulric answer to the great castle-shrine in Middenheim.
Some beasts are near-untameable, but at least you can pen them up until you have use for them.
Mutating energies of Chaos constantly infect the many wolf species of Norsca, producing all manner of lupine abominations.
Within these caverns, local tribesmen leave offerings to keep the ferally-mutated champions at bay.
The various Norscan depictions of the Ruinous Ones are put on display for all to see.
Mysterious shamanic ritual helps bring even the most powerful and destructive mutant leviathans under the warband’s control.
All Trolls love a good cave, but the Norscan variety prefer them as frosty and frigid as possible.
Deep within the bog, fiendish thugs wallow in waiting until the calling of battle.
Frozen tunnels under the ancient ice harbour unimaginable nightmares, offering no shelter from Chaos’ mutating influence.
Deep within an icy labyrinth strewn with the gnawed corpses of once-mighty heroes, sits the Troll King’s rocky throne.
Norsemen guard their possessions and keep themselves safe from the harsh land's many predators.
Watch Towers are erected if a settlement grows to the extent that it is considered worth guarding against external terrors.
The militia forced to protect the camp tend to be angrier, more bloodthirsty, and hell-bent on having their day.
In the harsh north, to wage war is to subsist.
Vast rewards of war flow in freely to those adept at the art of perpetual killing.
A place to stockpile the trinkets, jewels, and treasures pillaged from those now either enslaved or dead.
For a Marauder, a drawn weapon must taste blood, unless he is sparring with younger tribesmen to ready them for combat.
The Chieftain's chosen Warriors and Huscarls sit apart from the rest of the tribe in their own camp, as befits their status.
Often formed from the upturned hulls of old longships, a hall is where a Chieftain will feast and receive visitors.
A monument dedicated to the Crow God has been erected here – all will be befouled before it feasts on their decaying flesh!
A monument dedicated to the Eagle God has been erected here – all fear its looming shadow cast from above!
A monument dedicated to the Hound God has been erected here – all fear the feeding frenzy that is to come!
A monument dedicated to the Serpent God has been erected here – all fear that which slithers from the depths of Norsca!
Killing is more than just a sport – it is an experience that brings one closer to the Gods.
The favour of the Dark Ones does not come easily – blood must be spilt by the gallons; war must be waged!
Permanent war paint is one way that Norscans attract the gaze of their Gods and show their devotion to slaughter.
The white-hot irons of the Dark Furnace sear symbols of the tribe and their Gods directly onto living flesh.
Whether through mutation or mutilation, Norscans consider disfigurements and scars to be blessed markings of war.
In a Norscan occupation, those not enslaved will often end up burned alive as an offering to the Masters.
Norscan raiders sometimes place the rotting corpses of their dead in a ceremonial circular arrangment for display to the Gods.
To draw their Gods' attentions outside of battle, Marauders duel in Blood-Groves to spill each other’s blood in deathly combat.
Whenever possible, the skeletons of kings and champions slain by the Northmen are kept still adorning their priceless crowns and valuable armour.
Where the warriors lay their head is home – until the next raid.
As more warriors flock to the cause of murder and plunder, the outpost grows.
By reclaiming and reshaping the coast, an outpost can be more strategically defended against attacks from both land and sea.
Wharfs are platforms jutting out of the water, allowing ships to be boarded easily.
Norsca’s ship-building workshops enable their raiding Marauders to be the infamous scourge of the Old World’s seas.
From their raiding ports the Northmen pour out into all directions, intent on sending the world to wrack and ruin.
In a brutal land where war is the natural state, strongholds are necessary to assert effective authority.
The greater the Norscan stronghold, the more bloodthirsty killers that can be drawn to a warlord's banner.
The Norse tribes are mainly nomadic, making their camps where they may and moving on when the dark energies wane.
During a gathering of tribes or 'moot', many sacrifices are thrown into a large fire pit as the Chieftains parley.
The most permanent Norse settlement is a shanty village, close to a wharf, with a crude meeting hall at its centre.
Mutant pelts, with their unique textures and qualities, do not come cheap due to being highly difficult to obtain.
Treating and colouring beast-skins requires the use of lethal concoctions, a hazardous task best left to the thralls.
A living, breathing slave is much more valuable than the soulless vehicle of rotting flesh left after he dies.
Smiths are usually thralls, stolen from the south and kept alive for their skills, with access to a very basic smithy.
Higher forge temperatures offer more than just bigger and harder axes, but also useful things like beast-barding and chariot modifications.
“Don’t get too close – it burns with the hellish heat of the instability between worlds!”
Taken from the steppes of the Northern Wastes, Norse steeds are kept at crude shielings, feeding on diluted blood.
In tribal villages, steeds are kept in corrals, which stops them from wandering too far and becoming Manticore quarry.
As the war-gathering grows, stables become more necessary to keep the myriad mounts and beasts confined and separated – especially from each other.
When attackers are foolish enough to challenge a Norscan enclave, these ramparts drip crimson, drenched in their blood.
The fleshless faces of the dead stare out in warning to all enemies of the tribe.
Nothing saps the courage out of an enemy like a massive wall of dead bodies.
The Chaos Gods exist, as undeniable as the night. They are worshipped at Ruinous Altars, intended for sacrifice and more.
The larger a village becomes, the more significant and vile its shrine to the Dark Gods.
Wherever dark energies can be channelled, the seers commune with godlings and daemons to guide the tribe towards war.
To worship war is to endlessly indulge in it until death, or into immortality – whichever comes first.
Goblin Big Bosses have a big tent, bigga than the lads’ tents with more skulls on it.
A status symbol, a show of the Boss’ rising power and a place he can "ang me boots".
Goblins have keener sight than Orcs, so the "scrawny gits" generally man the watch towers.
Orcs that get guard duty are not the Boss’ chosen boyz, they probably skulked at the back during a charge.
Bone is a plentiful material for the Savage Orcs, and they use it all manner of ways.
The bone crafter dwelling is easily recognisable due to all the clattering bone fetishes that hang from its roof.
Naturally, the Savage Orc Warboss’ favoured bone carver gets to work in the Hut of Bones.
The boyz need big open spaces to swing their choppas about.
A large area set aside for the belligerent gits to slap each other about.
This is where Big ‘Uns are forged and many teef lost to gambling.
Savage Orcs are nomadic, but there are certain areas, deep in the Badlands, where they gather.
A Savage Orc camp is an even more disorganised rabble of tents than a traditional Orc settlement.
Savage Orcs can Waaagh! just like any Greenskin, giving thanks to Gork or Mork before charging off.
The Halflings’ diminutive stature masks a ravenous appetite, and as you might expect, highly-developed culinary skills; as such, their cauldrons bubble day and night!
The Order of Merciful Sisters of Sigmar dedicate their lives to recovering Warpstone from across the world and bringing it to Sigmar's Rock for safekeeping.
These structures lie in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
While the Archecclesiastium is technically the governing council of Myrmidia's cult, it has become the main temple's name by association.
The Knights of the Blazing Sun are dedicated to Myrmidia. Their large chapter house is emblazoned with her likeness.
The Bokha Palace is the seat of the ruling Tzars, a whole wing of which is fashioned from Ice Magic.
The Lady herself blessed the Morceaux Valley, washing the land with crystal water from the Grail.
The finest Bretonnian wines can be found in the Bordeleaux dukedom and the finest grapes in the Morceaux Valley.
Vintners gather the grapes blessed by the Lady, turning them into wine for future generations.
The wine market is a bustling and often dangerous place, as casks and bottles of the best vintages are sold for many gold coins.
Brightstone is highly valuable. It's therefore a pity that the mines at Mount Gunbad are infested with Night Goblins.
The Altdorf Colleges of Magic teach gifted students from across the Old World in the ways of Battle Magic.
The Altdorf Colleges of Magic teach gifted students from across the Old World in the ways of Battle Magic.
Surrounding the colleges are many conclaves, unions and societies where Wizards share knowledge and secrets.
Surrounding the colleges are many conclaves, unions and societies where Wizards share knowledge and secrets.
There are many docks in Erengrad - the 'Doorway to Kislev' - goods arrive here from Bretonnia, Marienburg and even Norsca.
Known simply as "the harbour", Erengrad is one of the largest ports, despite being under the control of its infamous Guilds.
The port encompasses the harbour and docks, from the bay to the mouth of the Lynsk.
The Slayer Hold of Karak Kadrin houses the greatest shrine to the Ancestor God, Grimnir, the first Slayer.
Sat atop the Ulricsberg, the fortress-temple at the heart of Middenheim dominates the city.
Da Dropz are where the Orcs like to relieve themselves; they particularly enjoy doing it in enemy settlements.
Greenskins like to "let da world know" a place has been conquered in the strongest (and stinkiest) way possible!
When a heap of crap isn't humiliating enough, the Greenskins can really "go for it" with a towering pillar of the stuff!
A stinky idol is not only a message to the enemy but a tribute to Mork (or Gork), using readily available materials.
A Troll's face made out of poo can be an intimidating thing to come across, depending on the quality of the "sculpture" of course.
Where the Throne of Power lies when in residence; where the High King sits reading the Dammaz Kron.
Knights Panther chapter houses are located deep within Middenland, although detachments can be found in armies across the Empire.
Marienburg is not a safe place in which to loiter, although the riches that pass through make it worth the risk.
The greater harbour of Marienburg lies past the Manannspoort Sea, just beyond Rijker's Isle.
Marienburg's infamous port, the Rijkspoort, is where the majority of the 'legitimate' goods arrive.
The foundry districts of Nuln are full of choking soot, as the forges burn night and day churning out Imperial artillery.
The Gunnery School is a centre of excellence, where the nation's greatest artillerymen are trained and cannons forged.
The Reiksguard is barracked in Altdorf. However, they maintain battle-ready fortresses scattered throughout the Empire.
Savage Orcs are nomadic, but there are certain areas, deep in the Badlands, where they gather.
A Savage Orc camp is an even more disorganised rabble of tents than a traditional Orc settlement.
Savage Orcs can Waaagh! just like any Greenskin, giving thanks to Gork or Mork before charging off.
The current capital of the Empire and seat of the Reikland Emperors. Altdorf is a large, cosmopolitan city-port full of wonders and danger.
Once the proud Hold of Karak Drazh, it is now the most formidable of Orc Strongholds, in the hands of the Red Fang tribe, until very recently.
Drakenhof is the sprawling ancestral fortress of the von Carstein bloodline. Ever since the coming of Vlad it has been the de facto political centre of Sylvania.
Formed in an ancient Elven stronghold many centuries ago, the city of Couronne houses the palace and ruling court of King Leoncoeur.
Karaz-a-Karak, known as Everpeak, capital of the Karaz Ankor. It is the richest, deepest, and most powerful of all Dwarfholds.
The tower stands in the heart of Great Cathay, a beacon of the Dragon Emperor's glory.
With thick walls and looming towers, the fortress is the bulwark of Wei-Jin's defences.
The grand palace is a symbol of opulence, paying homage to the Celestial Dragon's power.
The Celestial City rises above Wei-Jin, a shining symbol of Cathay's glory and the awe of all who stand in its shadow.
Magnificent is too small a word for a city known by all as the home of endless wonders and the seat of the Dragon Throne.
Once thought to be the greatest city in the world, Wei-Jin now lies in ruins, its wonders buried beneath a blanket of rubble and ash.
The nations of man enjoy a good tourney, especially the Bretonnians whose Knights relish showing off their skills to the smallfolk.
Such secrets that the innkeeper Franz Lohner does not know probably aren't worth knowing to begin with.
Taal's shrines are rustic abodes, small circular buildings with conical roofs, topped with the skull of a stag.
The greatest temple to Taal is found in Talabheim, the cratered city at the centre of the Empire.
Wharfs are platforms jutting out of the water, allowing ships to be boarded easily.
Whether man-made or natural, a harbour is a place for vessels to wait out Stromfels' rage.
Large port-cities are strategically key during wartime, for they are home to its great fleets, both military or mercantile.
Shrines of Myrmidia can be found in most southern provinces. They are well ordered, martial places, as befits their deity.
Myrmidia's temples are some of the grandest structures in the southern nations, reflecting how liked the goddess is.
Located in the barrows or tombs of long-dead Chieftains are dusty racks of aged weaponry, still sharp despite the centuries.
The most treasured and arcane possessions are kept in reliquaries, many made safe from looters… until now.
Often seen on Corpse Carts, balefire braziers contain an infernal flame that spreads a foul contagion.
A balefire hearth is a larger structure than a mere brazier - a raging hellfire inferno contained in a large, unholy fire pit.
Deep in the woods stands a hovel, surrounded by cruel fetishes. From its chimney pumps balefire smoke to wither the lands.
The crypts of Sylvania can be dangerous places, for ghouls lurk and feed on the rotting remains within.
To summon vile minions, a circle must be etched in the ground, with symbols of a dead language scrawled around it.
An infernal lodestone is planted inside a binding circle, summoning the most powerful of all spirits as it glows.
Graveyards and cemeteries are ubiquitous - a particular favourite source of "fresh recruits" for Necromancers.
Ancient warriors are found in barrows, usually at the sites of forgotten battles or the former seats of long-dead Chieftains.
The richer and more powerful the warrior, the grander his tomb. Such mausoleums contain great prizes for Dark Magic wielders.
The trees in Sylvania are as evil as its denizens, for they shelter many predators such as Fell Bats and Dire Wolves.
Sylvania's woods are dingy copses of twisted, half-rotted trees that claw what nourishment they can from the bone-strewn soil.
Dark and yellow-leafed forests surround the wind-swept moors of Sylvania, where criminals and far darker, hungrier, things lurk.
A pile of writhing corpses from which a shambling patrol of Zombies will emerge.
Throughout the cursed realm stand watchtowers of bone. Within are the Grave Guard - always on duty and ready to strike.
From private collections to tomes gathered in temple vaults, Necromancers will do anything to seek out forbidden lore.
Any Necromancer worth his infamy needs a dread tower from which to conduct blasphemous experiments and research.
This mass grave acts like a locus for Necromancers and their ilk, for it contains many fresh bodies ripe for recruitment.
A vile place of discarded gravestones, statuary, rotting limbs, headless bodies that still crawl, and lots and lots of bones.
Ossuaries are the resting places of skeletal remains, originally reserved for Morr's greatest subjects, but long since defiled.
A common sight across Sylvania and beyond, the gibbet - or hanging cage - is where the living who displease their Undead lords often end up.
Another common sight in the Unliving realms are gallows - although hanged corpses rarely stay dead and can often be seen struggling to untie their nooses.
Deep in the red pits can be found mercury in the raw form of cinnabar. A material often used in Dark Magic rituals.
The Blood Mines are red as cinnabar - and occasionally Warpstone - are found here in significant seams.
Best not choose the dark green powder, though, it certainly isn't snuff!
To hunt here is to become the hunted, for the prey is vicious and probably dead already…
Should the smallfolk organise themselves, a whole expedition will venture into the haunted woods in search of game.
What is the Flayer? A myth, but one that is all too real.
Gold found here is always tarnished and far from the pure element so beloved by Dwarfs. Nevertheless, it has value.
When a Vampire Count discovers a large seam of gold, he will send his minions forth to scour it clean.
A great furnace with an ornate, brazen face, and yellow-green balefire within its sneering mouth.
The blackest iron ore can be found in the deepest pits, underneath the mountains upon which gothic castles perch.
Since before the building of Nagashizzar, Necromancers have used Zombies to burrow and mine mountains for their minerals.
Cursed iron ore is laced with Warpstone. Such mines are prized.
Burning with balefire, an unholy forge is a relic of Stirland's more prosperous days, now defiled and used by a Vampire's thralls.
The dread castles of Sylvania are made from stone shaped by stone cutters, under von Carstein's thrall.
There is an art to creating a memorable tombstone or grand mausoleum.
Some gargoyles are fashioned by sculptors - others just appear, as if they flew there themselves.
The low-born of Sylvania that have heartbeats must still make a living. Most do in the cursed fields, tending to withering crops.
Sylvanian peasants tend to wretched farms, continuing the pretence that the realm's nobles are kind and generous lords.
At night, the mill by the blood-clotted streams begins to turn, mixing grains with grinded bone.
Beneath the blood-clotted streams and rank sewage are pits of dense, dark clay.
Using the raw clay compound, urn makers create opulent vessels to carry the ashes of powerful beings.
Perhaps there is some spirit trapped within, burning in abject agony every time the kilns are lit?
Stagnant ponds can be found by their disgusting reek, the brackish water full of brine and other things…
The only thing that rises from the crumbling salt marshes of Sylvania are bony hands reaching toward the sky.
Deep in the dead marches are salt pans, containing piles and piles of bones, bleached and scoured white.
Foresting in Hunger Wood or the Spider Haunts is surely a fool's job?
Once part of Stirland's burgeoning timber industry, the sawmills have remained in a ruined, yet operational state since the Vampire Wars…
From the ruined sawmills, Zombie bearers transport their cursed loads to large sheds long-thought abandoned by mortals.
There is a cabin in the woods… a place where someone, or thing, keeps certain other things…
There is a cabin in the woods, you know, where darkness dwells eternally…
When a Vampire drinks an "aged red" from a wine glass, chances are it hasn't been made from grapes…
Sylvanian orchards contain low-hanging, spooky trees, whose thorny branches are as likely to grab a passer-by as provide fruit.
The Vampire Counts crave the illusion that they are nobles, and so they bottle their own "special" vintages.
The scattered hamlets of Sylvania are even more isolated, parochial and pathetic than those of the Empire.
The peasantry live in small communities of inter-related families, and never venture far from their hovels.
Townships are little more than larger villages, usually within sight of a grand castle - its shadow looming over the terrified denizens.
When a Vampire marches forth, the cities of other realms fear - for should the Night Lord invade they become accursed places.
Dread, gothic citadels are scattered throughout Sylvania. They grow more ominous as their chief resident grows in power.
Within the tomb of the Vampire lies its coffin, filled with loam from Lahmia. It is where the beast rests, waiting to be awoken…
A Vampire's keep is quite literally its castle - a dark, gothic stronghold from which it plots and assembles its forces.
Gory fetishes are used to chain spirits to the insubstantial barriers known as ghost fences. To cross it without wards is a foolish act.
Walls of wood, stone, bone and skulls are used by the master of the Undead to form defences and instil terror.
Larger walls form mighty bulwarks that can be infused with Dark Magic to keep out and curse the enemy.
Honour mine father in death as in life…
The centuries-old wreckage of two beached Black Arks provide the Druchii with their most solid naval foothold in Albion.
Returned to its former glory, this great port is now as defensible as the mighty Black Arks that once stood in its place.
This once-bustling port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
